I do believe in reductionist dualism, everything can be explained in terms of the interactions of the constituent particles of a system. So, according to that, determinism seems more correct. So, everything, including the physical universe is not really "deterministic". Probability lies beneath it all. So, even though we reject the possibility of a separate entity called mind that can make free decisions, we are still left with a indeterminate, and possibly random world.
(This is just what I think, and I may as well be wrong. I would very much like to be corrected by others in the comments.)

My philosophical argument:
1) Everything in the universe is governed by physical laws
2) Physical laws can be expressed as a mathematical formula.
3) We - our brains, our bodies, everything - are part of the universe.

Conclusion: There is a mathematical formula that can express everything in the universe.

So, there is a formula that can describe how every neuron in every person's brain will fire and how everything around them in the physical world will move and create input, etc. This formula is far too complicated to ever calculate, but it exists. Ergo, there is a formula that describes the future, and therefore the future is predetermined, and therefore we don't have free will.

It's a very uncomfortable conclusion, but I see no way out of it - we don't have free will.

I think a better explanation is indeed what Devs explored in that series: Everett's Many-World interpretation of quantum physics; ie the idea that every choice we make creates different branches of reality where we made a different choice or got a different result.
So there IS free will, but it can also be sort of seen as deterministic because everything that CAN happen, WILL happen in some version of reality... we are simply perceiving a train of consciousness in one branch of reality, and the universe splits into various realities with every choice made. However, it's not actually deterministic... the result was not determined by some initial state... there are random events such as the appearance of virtual particles and cosmic background radiation and the movements of subatomic particles, which bubbles up into mutations and sudden events in the macroscopic world that do have causes, but not all of which can be traced back to one event.

This principle CAN be tested. We can prove or disprove this idea via mathematical principles (which Everett already did) and also can one day create a device that can perhaps peer into other realities, or create other realities like they do in Devs.
Furthermore, quantum physics shows that this is already the case on the smallest level... that all possibilities exist, but that trying to measure/observe a possibility with precision collapses it into a (likely) random result.

It was first manufactured in the United States in 1893 by wheat millers in Grand Forks, North Dakota.[1] The product made its debut at the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, Illinois. Also, I'd like to share how I think of the Universe and determinism.

I believe the Universe to be like a simulation in which every single thing at any point in time is determined by the starting variables of the simulation. If you'd start a second identical simulation, it would follow the same rules and history would be the exact same, your decision to eat a certain breakfast on a certain day would be the same.

And the fact that there are so many starting variable (and so many tiny details as consequences of those variables) is what gives us the illusion of choice. Because we can't see the intricate causes of our actions, we feel like they are free, but they're not, they're just intricate and would have been wildly different if the context would have been ever so slightly different (think butterfly effect).

Now, there is one flaw in this conception of the Universe. But I don't think it actually invalidates my model. It is quantum mechanics. It's the seemingly random of the infinitely small. But I believe that quantum is just the same as our actions. Not random, just unpredictable by our current means because of how intricate it is.

Although, if quantum were in fact random then my model would fail and if we were to run the same simulation, it would be completely different. But it would still be deterministic, since randomness is not the same as choice. I don't think there is such a thing as choice, only accepting that things are as they are.

It definitely seems like we have free will, but is it just an illusion?
Free will seems to be mostly an illusion. Anything we do just seems to be an effect of many different factors that caused it. We can’t control most of our emotions, such as sadness or anger, or physical aspects, like hormones or blood pumping, but does that mean we can’t control when we hurt someone too? Is it really not our faults for murder or physical harm if our actions were determined from the beginning? Why are we punishing people for the actions they had no real control over? To me this means that we have some sort of free will or this predicament would have no solution. My solution to this is God’s intervention into our seemingly static lives. (more explanation below)

Do you believe in fate?
I think our fate is determined from the beginning, but smaller choices in between point A and point Z can be changed with our free will. If God really had every little aspect of all of history planned from beginning to end, we’d all be living a story where God purposely produced pain and suffering into our lives. If we don’t cause bad things to happen, then the only other agent is God. And if the Bible portrays God accurately then that God would not intentionally do that to His creation. Either the Bible is lying that God really cared so much about us that He sent His only son to save us from OUR OWN sin, or God gave us the free will to CHOSE to sin against Him. God would have known we would sin from the start, but by Him adding the option to disobey Him in the first place it reveals His true aspirations of giving us the power of our own personal choice. We can’t ignore all the evidence we find in nature and around us, so perhaps we can’t control every aspect of our bodies or desires (as shown by the video) but a metaphysical agent or something outside this universe influencing our thoughts could break the chain of predetermined actions. So maybe God’s metaphysical reality influencing our own has allowed us to create our own realities, giving us true free will, but still leaving a determined end to this all that we cannot avoid.

An argument in favor of free will:
1. For people saying that everything that has happened has led us to this moment, one can only connect dots in the past. If something wouldn't lead to something else, then we will have a very abrupt flow of time.
2. If everything is certain, then one should be able to determine with complete certainty what with happen in the future, could be tomorrow, after a week, month, year or decade. But we can't. This can be because of 2 reasons - a) There are just too many variables for one to account for while foretelling the future. b) There is indeed an unknown factor which is human decision making.
Of course there can be both the reasons combined too. But till someone can perfectly tell the future, it's safe to say that we have free will.

Meditators observe the inner workings of their own minds in great detail; on retreats longer than 5-6 days with no talking, reading, writing, no TV, music, just sitting, walking, an occasional meal -- the mind slows down and your powers of mindfulness and concentration become strong and flexible enough to catch a lot of details that we simply can not notice otherwise.  That's when you might be lucky enough to experience "insight" into the deep nature of our human condition - insights that have the power to break down previously-held models of and beliefs about reality, human potential, mind/body, etc.  In the Buddhist context, these moments of profound insight are "liberating", that is, they liberate us from inaccurate, unnecessary, neurotic habits of mind/body.  If you can get past the initial reaction of "I would never do that!" and do the work that at first only demonstrates just how conditioned and "not free" we are...most of the time...then we discover just how rare it is that we take an action that is truly free, so I guess I agree with the determinists for 90%-97% of human decisions/actions, but if you take the time and do the work to actually see for yourself in the moment to moment lived stream of consciousness, perception, cognition, reaction, volition, action -- and to the degree that I have, I would put freedom down to 3-5%.  (Spent more than 24 months of my 55 years of life on mindfulness retreats - not that I recommend the longer retreats, like 3 months - but I do recommend doing at least one time in life a 9-12 day mindfulness retreat.  A weekend or a 4 even 5 day retreat is not long enough to get the really shocking spontaneous insights that can rock one's world).

I had this conversation with my girlfriend the other day while we were writing a paper on determinism, and we both concluded that determinism is real, in fact, while free will is not. Yet, what's different in our conclusion - something that I was really hoping to see in this video - was that although determinism is real, humans, luckily, act as if it isn't. In other words, since determinism is real, acting likewise will inevitably lead humans to collectively become the worst they can be, simply because everyone could rationally argue that they are not responsible for any of the shitty things they do, and neither for all of the good things they could have done but they didn't. There would be no valid ground on which one could be blamed for anything. As said in the video, determinism doesn't leave room for responsibility, cause that can only make sense within the free-will concept. Thus, by acting as if free will is something valid and real, we deterministically act better, not just individually, but collectively, because we want for the others to hold us responsible for the good things we do and the bad things we don't do. Having said that, yeah, determinism is real, and because it is, WE MUST act as if it's not so that we can strive to become the best we can, instead of giving up to the entropy by becoming life's worst nightmare.

A mother is alerted and warned that she and her three children are going to be murdered at an unexpected future time by an unknown killer
 
The unknown killer has a plan to murder the family at a specific time and place
 
Five people approach the mother at different times with partial information regarding the murders of her family
 
Each of the five people give her information that – even when considered together – is not enough information for her to know how to avoid the killing of her family
 
The mother makes several, thorough and exhaustive attempts to know more about the murder plot – but fails
 
 
The 'five people' are your five sensory organs: sight, sound, touch, taste and smell
 
The 'partial information regarding the murder plot obtained from the five people' is the sum total of the information your brain receives and stores via your five sensory organs
 
The 'mother's knowledge of the murder plot' is the total of the partial information received from your five sensory organs that your brain receives and stores 
 
'The unavailable, remainder of the information required to prevent the murder' is The DIVINE REALM and The DIVINE CONTROLLER residing and operating therein which your brain is incapable of perceiving or knowing – no matter how hard you try, or how many attempts you make

The symbol is not that for which it stands.  Most of us are fooled into thinking that the rules of everyday language concerning how our words (symbols) are related to each other also govern the physical universe.  It is hard to overcome what I call the tyranny  of everyday language.  Philosophers, scientists, religionists, etc. are all subject to it - no matter how brilliant they might be.  The pointing finger is not the moon.  Freedom and responsibility are just necessary fictions.  Society seems to need to pretend they are somehow real, and of course the same goes for "free will".  These concepts help societies to function, and are embedded in our everyday language.  To conclude that therefore they are "real"  in a deep philosophical or even scientific sense, outside of  the conventions of society and language, is unwarranted.   The proofs that they exist are inevitably circular, and based on nothing more than grammar.     Many people find it emotionally important to believe in them nonetheless.   So be it.

Sure, you might have more reason to Chose A instead of B. Environment and other causes will probably make it more likely for you to choose oatmeal instead of cereal. But unlike a computer, we don't run on these algorithms, and they are not law.
We can say that all these reasons for you choosing oatmeal are what made you choose oatmeal this morning. 99 times out of a hundred you would choose oatmeal because of the reasons. But what if I knew all these reasons, but I still decide to choose cereal? All theses causes are in favor of oatmeal, but still I have the freedom to choose cereal if I want to. Realistically, most days, we all choose the alternative with the best causes for it, but it doesn't guarantee it. A robot would always choose the "best" alternative, but humans make bad decisions, so doesn't this prove that we have free will? In this scenario, you could say that 99% of the time you are going to choose oatmeal, because of external factors, but it doesn't GUARANTEE it. I COULD choose cereal, I'm probably not going to because it's the worse choice, But I still could. I am going against the algorithm through my exertion of free will.


We also need to high-light that there is a difference between reflex, instinct, subconscious decisions and conscious decisions.


A reflex might come from your brain, or your spine. These are actions which make without any conscious effort. When you hear a loud noise, flinch and hide your head. When you touch a hot stove, you remove the hand even before you, the conscious you, have any idea of what's happened. You could almost call these "Choices made through an algorithm". Feel something hot = Remove hand. There are no alternatives, there is no thinking. There is no choice


Acting on instinct would be similar, but not automatic. This is gut feeling, going what you think is safest, making a decision without having the time to consciously consider all the available alternatives.
In these cases, you do not have free will, and if you knew all the factors, you could predict which choice is to be made.


And the one different from the previously mentioned would be a Conscious Decisions.
In this you get time to think, to ponder, to question, to argue. You hold an internal debate with yourself, and you, the philosophical you, is engaged in the decision making.
If you three identical red ball in front of me, and gave me 30 seconds to choose which one to pick, and then pick one, then you could never know which one I was going to pick. It's a pointless decision with no preference for either. You could say "Oh he's right handed so he's most likely going to pick the right one" Sure, maybe there is a higher chance of that. But not 100%. My free will, my conscience, the philosophical me, made the decision all alone. No sub conscience, no gut feeling, no algorithm is followed.

If there is no such thing as free will, then there is no such thing as a person and, thus, no such thing as reasoning, science, logic, beliefs, choices, bad, good, correct, incorrect, meaning and the list goes on.

On the Theory of Everything

Laplace famously suggested that a sufficiently powerful intellect could, if it knew the position and velocity of every particle at a given time, along with the laws of nature, calculate the position of any particle at any other time:

An intellect, which at a certain moment would know all forces that set nature in motion, and all positions of all items of which nature is composed, if this intellect were also vast enough to submit these data to analysis, it would embrace in a single formula the movements of the greatest bodies of the universe and those of the tiniest atom; for such an intellect nothing would be uncertain and the future just like the past would be present before its eyes.

Laplace — Essai philosophique sur les probabilités, Introduction. 1814

Although modern quantum mechanics suggests that uncertainty is inescapable, a unifying theory governing probabilistic assignments may nevertheless exist. But, man can affect changes in the universe in an undetermanistic fashion (Laplace's theory is only valid if man didn't exist).

The Bogey of Determinism

Let's suppose that determinism is true, that there is some set of human conditions C that are jointly sufficient to bring about an event a, in this case an action, which changes the movement of atoms in the universe. For anyone who knows the theory "C causes a," a is predictable from C. But now let's suppose I find out about this theory, and it is my action a that is in question. The set of conditions C is no longer complete, for there is now an additional condition - my knowledge of the theory "C causes a" - and so we need a new theory, according to which we can predict action a1, from the new set of conditions, C1 (C plus the fact that I know C causes a and the complications that brings about). Now let's suppose that one of the conditions included in C1 is the fact that I am a dishonest person, Accordingly we can be sure that in our new theory, a1 will be a different act from a, precisely its opposite where it is possible. But now we have a new theory, C1 causes a1," which takes into account this dishonesty and includes it as a variable in the theory. But suppose I come to know this new theory, thus adding a new condition to the set of condictions C1(C2), Out of dishonesty, I will now act in such a way as to falsify that theory, too. But, of course, a new theory would would predict that also, (as long as I don't find out about it.) Even if determinism is true, no one can know in advance what they are going to choose, not even a sufficiently "powerfull intellect." Determinism, then, is not an intelligble thesis. In other words, we can accept determinism without concern if we exclude humanity from the universe.

Einstein's discovery that time and space are illusions does not mean that determinism is valid, that the future has already happened. It means that time and space are relative.

What does
t stand for? It stands for the number measured by a clock. The
equations tell us how things change as the time measured by a clock
passes.
But if different clocks mark different times, as we have seen above,
what does t indicate? When the two friends meet up again after one has
lived in the mountains and the other at sea level, the watches on their
wrists will show different times. Which of the two is t? In a physics
laboratory, a clock on a table and another on the ground run at different
speeds. Which of the two tells the time? How do we describe the
difference between them? Should we say that the clock on the ground has
slowed relative to the real time recorded on the table? Or that the clock
on the table runs faster than the real time measured on the ground?
The question is meaningless. We might just as well ask what is most
real—the value of sterling in dollars or the value of dollars in sterling.
There is no “truer” value; they are two currencies that have value relative
to each other. There is no “truer” time; there are two times and they
change relative to each other. Neither is truer than the other.
But there are not just two times. Times are legion: a different one for
every point in space. There is not one single time; there is a vast
multitude of them.
The time indicated by a particular clock measuring a particular
phenomenon is called “proper time” in physics. Every clock has its proper
time. Every phenomenon that occurs has its proper time, its own rhythm.
Einstein has given us the equations that describe how proper times
develop relative to each other. He has shown us how to calculate the
difference between two times.7
The single quantity “time” melts into a spiderweb of times. We do not
describe how the world evolves in time: we describe how things evolve in
local time, and how local times evolve relative to each other. The world is
not like a platoon advancing at the pace of a single commander. It’s a
network of events affecting each other.
This is how time is depicted in Einstein’s general theory of relativity.
His equations do not have a single “time”; they have innumerable times.
Between two events, just as between the two clocks that are separated
and then brought together again, the duration is not a single one.8
Physics does not describe how things evolve “in time” but how things
evolve in their own times, and how “times” evolve relative to each other.*

Some Christians, especially the Evangelists like Mormons and Jehovah's Witnesses, attempt to inject logic into their religious thought. There is however a triad of logical impossibility common to most Christian reasoning, and that is that three incompatible precepts happily coexist. (Hang in there; free will pops up in a moment...) The three are 1. God is good; 2. God created everything; and 3. God knows past, present, and future.
Here's the difficulty: if God created everything, then God also created Hell. If God knows the future, then even before he created humans, he knew some of them would end up in Hell. This raises the issue of whether this is compatible with his being good.
The strongest (yet futile) argument against this is that God gave humans free will, and we get to decide how we will behave. Unfortunately for their reasoning, the question is not whether humans have free will here, but is whether God does. After all, if he knows the future, then he knows which of his creations will freely choose good over evil. Suddenly God's omnipresence becomes a curse instead of a blessing for Christian religious logic.
This brings up the concept of faith: faith is acceptance of something that cannot be logically determined. (There's that word (determined!") Thus it is possible for Mormons and other Evangelists to believe within an illogical framework; a possible difficulty for them is to recognize that it is indeed faith and not logic that is the basis for their beliefs.
Just to be fair, they are not alone in their faith: all of science and thus all scientists predicate their entire study and profession upon the unprovable assumption that the real world is knowable. This is an assumption, because there is simply no way to prove it, just as there is no ultimate way to prove or disprove determinism. Basing their lives on pure faith is truly a bane for scientists. With this understanding, we get to logically acknowledge that, if nothing else, the one thing both Evangelists and scientists have in common is a faith in unprovable assumptions!

This is just the "fine tuning" argument that theists use to help themselves understand the concept of the deity they worship reworked to help us understand the concept of the future. The future, like a deity, is just a concept. "Look at all the things that had to happen in order for me to be right here, right now, experience the things I'm experiencing at this exact moment!" is a fun high idea that comes from over-analyzing the past. Since hindsight is 20/20 and regret can ruin our present, the idea that the future has already been written is can be comforting. That way we don't feel bad about our decisions that don't go our way. If we just did what we were going to do regardless of any ability to do something else, then why regret that decision?

The truth is, though, that the future doesn't exist in any form other than conceptual. The past is also conceptual. We have nothing but now. We have ways of describing the past and capturing it on video even, but when we were recording it, it was still just the present. If someone could go back in time and observe us throughout our yesterday, they would likely see us making the same choices that they (being from the future) already knew we would be making. For us, though, it wouldn't be yesterday all over again, it would be our present still. We wouldn't make the same decisions because we have no choice in the matter, but because we would be using our past experiences and knowledge to act as we do and make the choices that we do. If you were to go to the future and watch my tomorrow, it wouldn't be tomorrow to me, it would be my future's present. Going back to your present with knowledge of my future wouldn't matter. I might do the things you saw when you visited the future, but I might do something different. The future is just a concept and we are constantly making all of our decisions in the now.

There is a difference between something you do being caused and something you do being influenced. Just because you can isolate influences, it doesn't mean that you know the cause. You can't ever have certainty about what causes someone to do anything because it is an infinite regression. And that's where the determinism philosophy breaks down. It conflates correlation with causation. Just because we can correlate certain actions with certain patterns, it doesn't mean that we know that those patterns caused anything because there is an infinite amount of factors that we do and don't know that can influence any event from the past and present, and because our minds are finite we don't know. And we can't even say for sure that a present event isn't caused by future events because we don't know for certain if time flows in a forward direction or not as subatomic particles appear to be able to go back in time and change their history.

Actually, existentialism would be a way to get out of this entire chain of causality. If like I do you do believe that absolutely nothing is determined then you can believe in free will. The hypothesis would be that there is no preexisting purpose or meaning for neither your own existence nor the existence of anyone or anything. The concept of causality would then have been created by mankind to explain a world that in itself neither need to nor can be explained. Same goes for basically every abstract concept such as order, truth, moral to only name a few. What is really interesting about this theory is that it is in itself more scientific than the determinism on which is based science. The falsifiability of a theory is essential for it to be considered a scientific theory (Karl Popper). Yet, it is impossible to refute the determinism of all things since not knowing the cause of a specific event doesn’t prove that it doesn’t exist. When the theory of existentialism could be proven wrong by finding the primary cause that would the existence of everything. The idea that human existence preceded meaning, logic, and causality would then be the most plausible scientific theory which has yet to be refuted. When absolute determinism can’t be classified as more than a belief. If nothing is determined you have then no other choice than to accept the reality of Free will.

Hi ! :) I just wanted to add somethinmh to Libertarianism, since many many people conside it to be irrational and Libertarians deny the reasults of scientific reasearch. I think its quite important to say this, because Libertarianism is often put off as having no serious basis. Before i researched fo my essay i also thought in this way. It is actually not necessarily the case that Libertarians think that 1) Only our feelings are a good reason to believe that we are free. 2) A Libertarian does not have to believe in body-mind-dualism. 3) A Libertarian is not necesarily somebody who believes in agent causation.

1) Some Libertarians justify their view by saying, that there are no good reasons to think Determinism has to be true. For example they might say, that the laws of nature are not supporting the idea of it or that in neurosciences there might only be a korrelation of mental (feeling, belives....) and neuronal states, but not a causal one . So there is not only the emotion-releted justification of this thesis. They might say that, as long there is no good reason to think Determinism is true, we can stick to our feeling.

3) There are also Libertarians believing in event causation instead of agent causation. Libertarians do not necesserily say that it is wrong, that f.ex. a person might be formed by socialisation or sth. Also they do not necessarily deny causation - but just a deterministic version of it. So accoridng to some of them causation does not necessarily mean that if event A happens, B necesssarily has to follow. They might interprete it f.ex. rather as a probabilistic relation. According to this understanding, a decision can be changed til the action actually happens. That means also that indeterminism has not to be thought of as lacking of causes and as only being set into relation with cases of luck. You do not have to deny causation to deny determinism - they are two differant things.

2) Again, Libertarians do not have to compleeetely deny the results of scientific research - they can just interprete them differently than a determinist would do. Since they do not have to be agant causalists there is also no reason for them to necessarily be a mind-body-dualist.

Entropy, dude. Our brains are closed systems. The more organized a brain is, the less organized its surroundings, aka the Universe. The more organized the Universe, the more chaotic our brains. Which means, as long as our brains go unobserved by the universe, its local spontaneity both is and isn't an infinute number of possible reactions to the last observation by the Universe. The next time the Universe observes our brain, the possible reactions we could have are finite and all equally possible, but we can only have one. So, we choose the reaction with least actions. To know which reactions have least actions, the brain has to observve the Universe, but when it does, it cannot observe itself, and can only observe a very small fraction of its surrounding environment, forcing it to guess. Boom. The Feinman Proof of Educated Choices.

I think free will is a properly basic belief in that it can be rightly believed (person is reasonable to form such a belief) as there is an absence of defeaters (other beliefs held that naturally contradict a basic belief). Basic beliefs become proper basic beliefs if there are no defeaters. If I deny free will, I would have to give up my belief that I can reason, but then this would undermine my current activity which is reasoning. It cannot be rightly believed that I do not have free will because there is a defeater in the denial of free will.


I wholly disagree with the positivist view that claims that beliefs cannot be properly held unless there's evidence for it because the positivist view is itself meaningless because there is no evidence to believe that beliefs held without evidence cannot be properly believed. Basically, positivism is self-referentially incoherent (or self-contradictory). This is not to say that it is false, but the claim is in itself meaningless, one cannot properly assign truth or falsity to it.

Determinism - Human choices are predetermined.
Fatalism - Everything is predetermined.

I read a great article once on how "big" things are objectively deterministic (Newtonian physics, action=reaction), while "small" things are impossible to predict (quantum mechanics, fundamental particles). The point he made was that we then have a world where we are free to choose, fulfilling the libertarian view, because the most deconstructed of our brain function is essentially unpredictable. Nevertheless, the large-scale consequences of our actions (the objects we put in motion) are deterministic through the laws of physics. Thus we have a world of agency, but also where cause and effect is bound by law.

Except that if we say that x necessarily causes y, it means that the existence of x is necessarily linked to the existence of y. There is therefore no possible world where x exists and y doesn't exist. In other words, it means that the existence of the cause (x) actually depends on its effect (y). Which means that x and y depend on each other and are the cause of each other. In a deterministic view, the past is cause of the future, but the future is also cause of the past.
A good argument against determinism is the humean argument : we never observe causality.We see actions following other actions. And we interpret this as if the following actions are the necessary result of the previous actions. But this interpretation doesn't seem to be logically necessary. On the contrary, it's logically problematic. As Kant put it: "How can we understand that because something exists, something else should then exist?" We could simply interpret this flux actions as a contingent or random flux.
Denying that something has a cause doesn't necessarily imply a logical contradiction. As Hume says, if a thing happens without a cause, it doesn't mean the nothingness is its cause: it just means that it doesn't have a cause.

So do you all one box or two box on Newcomb's Paradox?
That is, pretend a mysterious rich man who claims to be omniscient named Noah is offering people a choice. He presents his subject with 2 boxes: A and B. Box B always has $500 in it while in Box A Noah's put either $1000 or $0. Then Noah leaves the room, and the subject's choice is to either just take Box A or to take both boxes. The thing is, whenever Noah predicts his subject will just take Box A, he puts $1000 in Box A, and whenever Noah predicts the subject will take both boxes, he puts $0 in Box A.
Now pretend that you've observed this process for many many subjects (maybe 7 billion or so), and every single time, Noah has predicted the subject's choice correctly. You've researched magic tricks and tried to think of all kinds of tricks Noah could do to influence the boxes from outside the room, but you've managed to rule them all out. Noah has presented as much evidence as possible to show that he's allnoahing. You're also not allowed to bring any x-ray-like technology into the room to see what's in Box A.
So now you "choose" to play the game, because, hey, who doesn't want some money? Would you take just Box A or both boxes?
Maybe you think that it's in principle possible to have a perfect model of a human brain and Noah seems to have one, so you take just Box A since, if you didn't, Noah would have predicted that you're just the type of person to take both boxes and would have put less money in Box A. Or maybe you think it's more likely that the last 7 billion "people" to play the game were actually perfectly predictable automatons that the possibility that you don't have free will.

For those of you suffering an existential crisis thinking about this.

Two huge caveats.

First and most important - We don't know much of anything about the Universe, us and our place in it.
Centuries of scientific, philosophical and technological advancement and we still do not yet 'know' why some very ubiquitious things happen. An example would be dreams.
Why do we really dream?

I have almost no knowledge of nueroscience but the most authoritative expert cannot say for certain.

Just as determinism argues that free will is essentially ignorance of the intricacies of our own psychological processes when it comes to decision making...

The fact that we don't 'know' everything about life seems to indicate that even perfect causal chains may be influenced by things we are not yet cognizant of.
Ergo, Determinism may not be as bullet proof as it appears.

"I feel free" as a counterintuition to logic is a good springboard for an empirical observation - Feelings are not always logical. And we come to the second caveat.

Feelings and dreams are part of that great philosophical spelunking pit - an individual mind's inner experience... Thoughts, imagination, fears, doubts, feelings, emotions and eventually cognition.(consciousness?)

Everyone has an inner world which we do not know if or how is it separate from our external reality.

Our actions are influenced by feelings and inturn, reactions influence how we feel.

If strict, diamond hard determinism is true then all inner experiences (which we really do not understand that much - dreams!) is simultaneously determined i.e. logical and inevitable i.e. free from influence from any change.

But feelings are not logical and often can be changed without any external input ... Remember dreams?

The reason I bring dreams in is because some things cannot yet be causally explained. Almost all emotions arguably fall somewhere within this region.

Thus we come back to the comfort zone of free will and an uncertain but very plausible determinism besieging said zone.

Also, in response to 9:06, I think we do still have Personal Responsibility, to at least some degree. As stated at 6:43, the actions a sentient being takes can be determined by a few identifiable causes, namely beliefs, desire, and temperament. I will emphasize here that we can interact with and influence the minds of others and potentially cause them to substitute one belief for another, and treat others a certain way so as to influence their desires and/or temperament. Once we know this, if we agree with Kant and W.K. Clifford about our moral duty and epistemic responsibility, then we can recognize that changing people's beliefs (from incorrect beliefs to true beliefs learned from evidence-based science) and properly interacting with them (in ways that don't cause their desires or temperaments to be hostile or antagonistic toward you and your goals) are actions we can and even should consider ourselves responsible to take.

Even in a deterministic world, this seems to be the correct conclusion. We know that we can change their brains in ways that cause physical changes, so we know our actions could make people and the world better. Note: none of this changes the physical circumstances of the recipients before they receive this attention; they will either be mentally (aka physically) open for these positive changes, or they won't be. But if they are, and if you happen to be the only person who can or will be able to help them, is that not your duty? And, since you don't know exactly who will need your help in order to improve their lives, and you don't even know exactly what all the true beliefs are (if they can be known or numbered), we are called to action. At any given time, you only know what you currently know, so actively rout your ignorance and increase your knowledge. Experience what you can and increase your wisdom. Observe those around you and the beliefs they express and act upon, pay attention for exhibitions of false beliefs and see if you can identify the exact part of their beliefs that are false; see how these false beliefs impact those around them or even themselves.

Clearly we can see the potential here for improving something less that is currently than ideal. Some false beliefs are harmful to humans, other living beings, and the environment, like being against modern medicine when ill or injured, or refusing to learn the proper way to use weapons or drive a car or handle fire or anything dangerous, or dehumanizing others, or taking advantage of the weak, or causing fear and distrust by being afraid and distrustful of others different from you, or by practicing social behaviors that damage relationships and perceptions of the selves and the others, or by being greedy and ignoring externalities caused by selfishness (e.g. pollution from energy and transportation, cruel animal treatment for cheap and accessible meat), etc etc.

So, to me, this tells us that we have a responsibility and duty to further our own knowledge, reach out to others, interact with them in healthy ways, and help educate them to reach further knowledge for themselves as well. I mean...once we know this, we're either gonna do it or we aren't ('cuz determinism), but if I can successfully argue that it is our responsibility, whether or not we end up actually deterministically being caused to do it or not, learning of the duty and accepting the duty is still something that could cause any of us to take upon ourselves that duty and act on it and, thereby, possibly make the world a better place. Meaning I feel compelled to share this with all of you, some of whom may be convinced and then feel the same compulsion themselves and act on it, spreading the message further. It continues to spread to all who can be reached by it, changing whom it will along the way. It acts like a virus, goes viral, and becomes a meme (the original Dawkins definition).

Why do we want this? The more people who understand that we are not ultimately responsible for either who we are nor our current state that leads to our actions, and that troubled people who act at odds with society and/or the law can potentially be rehabilitated to help shape their minds closer to a state where they can more easily behave in a manner safe for reintegration back into society, then the more harmony and understanding we can spread, the more work will be done to help the unfortunate (it seems more fitting to use this term in a deterministic universe than, say, "evil"), the more crime we will end, the more impoverished we will uplift, the more peace we will substitute for violence, the more true knowledge we can acquire and achievements we can accomplish.

...kudos to anyone getting through all this.

I have a lot of problems with this one, the dismissal of free will seems way too eager here. Didn't we already have the discussion of whether the universe was cause and effect when we discussed God? In my opinion, the free will debate is very similar to the God debate. We'd discussed "infinite regress"- which is exactly what cause and effect is. If an effect requires cause, wouldn't that have to go back to infinity? And we know that, as science stands now, the universe is 13.8 billion years old, not infinite. Most observable effects do require causes. But, God created us "in his image." Perhaps the image isn't just physical? Perhaps this means we have some of his abilities? Perhaps we have the ability to create "uncaused effects."

It's like saying "all knowledge comes from books." While it's true that you get knowledge from reading books, they didn't originate in the book, obviously. Someone went out and discovered, experimented, then organized their thoughts into a book. They've used their minds to decide how the data they're reviewing fits into the world. In other words, knowledge originates in the mind. Writing a fiction novel is a similar idea. We have a vast, huge amount of character, plot, setting, and writing style options to choose from. And the ones I choose can be chosen at random or based on my preferences.

This argument could probably be easily picked apart, and I welcome interlocutors to do so, but in sum my argument is as follows:

Hard determinism is based on cause and effect. Cause and effect would be considered an infinite regress. Infinite regresses are impossible because the universe is finite years old. Therefore, hard determinism can't possibly be true.

In addition:
God created us in his image. This could mean he implanted in us his ability to change fate. If God created the universe and started the chain of cause and effect, and he implanted in us a far less powerful but similar ability, then we have the ability to create effects without cause. In other words, to make decisions which are not influenced by the world. Therefore, we can make decisions that aren't influenced by previous causes.

The denial of free will is rooted in the argument of determinism. That is, since we are all just a bunch of atoms and molecules interacting and combining according to very arcane and abstruse mathematical rules, our very thoughts, being a function of our brains, are merely the pre-determined side effects of these rules. (And since mathematical rules/laws of physics are absolute and absolutely infinite, everything is these rules; there are no distinctions between the rules and the objects which are said to act and interact according to these rules because everything is a direct and utter function of the laws of physics…in which case, how is it possible to claim the laws of physics actually govern anything? To say they govern themselves is pointless redundancy. )

And this completely destroys the deterministic argument against free will. Because what this means is that there is no such thing as truth. All ideas are equally valid, since according to deterministic protocol all ideas, being a function of brains governed by the inexorable laws of physics, are a function of the same mathematical rules. This being the case, it is impossible to make the claim “there is no such thing as free will, is true” or “there is such a thing as free will, is false” since both ideas are a function of brains governed by the exact same rules. And this is why they must and do appeal to a “superior enlightenment” based upon their elevated mathematical prowess. There is no rational explanation for why we must believe them, any more than there is a rational explanation for why the laity must submit to pastoral authority since both the pastors and the laity are, according to doctrine, fallen creatures and utterly prone to sin and delusion by their very nature.
To make the claim, “there is no such thing as free will” is to presuppose a person can actually know truth. But, again, according to the very argument against free will, itself, there is no such thing as a true thing versus a false thing since every idea is the product of the same deterministic rules. When people are not actually free to learn, because their minds are entirely governed by the laws of physics, then by definition they cannot actually know anything. To learn is to presuppose a difference between knowing and not knowing, and to presuppose a difference between a good idea (rational, or true) and a bad one (irrational, or false). If there is no such thing as free will (the individual application of perceived knowledge…between a true thing/good thing and a false thing/bad thing, either based upon contextual circumstance or upon foundational philosophical assumptions), and all beliefs and actions are merely a function of brains which are all equally and absolutely governed by mathematical rules, then there can be no difference. There can be no real ideas, which means there can be no real thought. Which means there can be no thought at all. Which means there can be no consciousness. Which means that people like Stephen Hawking and Sam Harris cannot claim that free will is an illusion, as though this is some truth that they can actually know, and know as true, and of which they should seek to convince others, as though making the point is anything but a colossal waste of time. Because you can’t convince people out of an idea that they don’t actually believe, and this because they don’t believe anything, because their contrary thoughts are merely the effects of the same deterministic forces which produced yours

Fun thoughts on determinism: If it is the case that all of the factors of your past affect every choice and moment of your present, it is also necessarily true that every choice of your present will affect your future. As such, to what extent does awareness of determinism allow you to manipulate/ avoid it? If you are cognisant that past moments determine present, and ergo present moments determine future, you should be able choose your future within the scope of options available to you.

Question 2: What are the primary factors of the past that drastically affect the present? My best guess/example is education. The more you know, the more you know you can know. Ya know? (cheeky, but bear with me). Everyone, to some extent, is unaware of just how many things they are ignorant of. Not understanding that things exist very literally limits your ability to comprehend of their reality, and as such limits your ability to incorporate them in to your growth as a human. If all you know is violence and misery, that is what your future will hold. If all you know is a white picket fence, 40 hour work weeks for a strangers company, and a deep seated hope your children don't become sociopathic, the future life is likely to follow that knowledge path. Education literally opens up mental pathways that allow people to use goals to shape their growth. Such a basic concept, but an incredible one none the less.

Okay, I’m sorry, but the problem I have in this video is that it supports Hard Determinism so much, it basically makes it sound less like an informational piece and more like a persuasive video to say, “Reject Libertarianism! Embrace Hard Determinism!” And I’m sorry if this is determined to, but I’m going to say it:

I have found good arguments for libertarianism beyond “we feel free”. Yes, a part of it is Quantum Mechanics, and as a whole, according to the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, the hard determinism has fallen out of favor since quantum mechanics has indicated that things aren’t as simple as “causality is everything.” Obviously, randomness doesn’t “prove” free will, but there are other arguments.

Existential Comics did a comic about this, “A Study In Compatibilism” where the person who believed in free will made the argument that because the laws of nature in science were malleable (theories can and are proven wrong sometimes) and that humans have a will whereas things like a rock or baseball don’t also needs to be a factor as well.

Along with this, there’s no talk about the Fixed vs. Growth mindsets and what they think, studies about how neurology, psychology, and sociology can influence our thinking but not completely overrule us, as well as how our mental states can influence our physical states and we can recognize when our own brain is tricking us, and the article “What it’s like to be a bat?” it feels pretty bias.

The biggest problem, though, is that no actual libertarians or their views are mentioned, which makes things worse.

I’m sorry; I know NONE of these prove free will exists—I’m not even trying to take a side there—and I know this response could just be determined as well, but simply put I’m not going to stand back and see what is supposed to be someone who is trusted with teaching us this stuff in an unbiased fashion basically encourage us—intentionally or unintentionally—that the only way to be scientific and smart is to take one side and say all oppositions are just “feelings”.

Interesting piece but no mention of quantum randomness (maybe that comes in the next part). This seems to be (as far as current scientific understands) genuine randomness not just an event whose routes are so complex that we can't back trace them. There literally seems to be no reason why a particle's super position resolves to the given position that it does. This means that we can't say that everything had to turn out the way it did, even though it did. More helpfully it means we couldn't determine the future (in all cases) because of the lack of cause (maybe there is an underlying reason for quantum randomness-stay tuned). But it's still not free will. Either there was a reason for an action in which case that reason locked it in place, or there wasn't, in which case it was purely random-still not free will. At a macro level it is often linguistically useful to arbitrarily define a given point in a process as the point of decision, but it was still either forced by something before it or it was genuinely random. Not only does free will not exist (in my opinion-feel free to disagree-see what I did there), but even the concept of free will has no meaning when you get close up, much like the thing with the onion skins.

Scientists who believe in determinism believe that the Brain is in control of conciousness.  Scientists who believe in free will believe that conciousness is separate from the brain.  All scientific studies of the brain show that the brain is deterministic, however, neuroscience has shown that conciousness is separate from the brain and so although many of our choices are derived from the brain these can be overridden by conciousness if time allows and therefore are free will.  The further we postulate into the future or outside the constraints of our normal lives the greater the conscious input.  The closer we come to making a decision to act the more deterministic / automated it becomes.  A pianist's thoughts of what notes and how to play them are in the future but the current actions of the fingers have already been determined and are automated and governed by the brain.  A more obvious manifestation of this is the postulation of a new theory that is not based on any observable and measurable outcomes and in no way can come from a determinism cause based on prior results from prior causes In one's life but are purely based on abstract conscious thought such as Einstein's theory of relativity.

I would pose a counter to your argument that are mental functions are simply biological functions and thus obey the same rules. Which is that there is a difference between our nervous system and say a tornado, and that difference is memory. Our nervous system is the latest in a long serious of evolution's in the physical world and one of the hallmark developments of that system, which others do not possess, is the ability to retain events of the past in the form of memories. And because we have memory we are able to retain what happens to us, where as a weather system does not. And I think that matters. That ability of our nervous system to retain memories of decades worth of causation's and then send signals to our muscles long after those causation's have actually occurred is a fundamental difference between us and a tornado. A tornado will only react to weather systems that are happening in the moment. What the climate was a year ago will never factor into if a tornado will develop, while humans can factor in memories of previous events. And so I would argue that retention of previous events is what gives us the foundation for free will.

We all have free Will. The thing that determines the perception of free will, is whether or not the individual perceives their conscious experience as a product of the physical world, or the physical world as a product of consciousness. I am humble enough to know that my entire perception of the physical world, is a conscious projection. I never actually interact with a physical world outside of this subjective experience. Conscious experience of the universe is the only thing we are actually sure of. There doesn't even need to be a physical universe. If the physical universe is a projection of consciousness, then all the limitations that predetermine outcomes, are a choice made through free Will.

So why would a singular consciousness or collective consciousness impose limitations? The simple answer is that unlimited consciousness is undefined without limitation. Without being defined, conscious experience ceases to exist, returning the collective consciousness to a singular consciousness, which instantaneously limits itself, expanding conscious experience simultaneously. This is why in physics, we find proof of both nothing before everything, and everything from nothing; at the same time, we find evidence that the universe is layers of limited possibilities, with the only thing anchoring reality being individual and the shared conscious perspective. Essentially, we are simply unaware that we always have free Will, because the true choice is the perspective, and not between the limited actions we can take within our perspective.

There is a conscious experience where we are all aware of this truth. In that place, individuals see themselves as part of the shared conscious experience, and limit themselves in a way where everyone is cared for as if they are caring for themselves. There is also a place where there is no perception of the collective experience, and it's full of suffering. Even in the world of suffering, peace can be found within, because we never lose our free Will, we only lose sight of it.

Suppose determinism is true, we would be rational to believe it, right? But if determinism is true, then my belief in it was determined by non-rational causes, not necessarily connected to the truth of the statements nor the soundness of the argument. Therefore, it wouldn't be a rational belief. I would be predetermined to believe the conclusion just as others would be to reject it, independent of the actual validity of the argument or the truth of the premises. But we already stated above that we are rational to believe in determinism. So either we abandon determinism or rational belief. But if we abandon rational belief, then we abandon our reason to believe in determinism. Therefore we abandon determinism.

I'd love to see a deeper dig into the belief - desire - temperament aspects. I feel like it could be sliced more...

For example, it seems that some of the aspects of my temperament are endemic at a kingdom level (ie mammals), some at a species level (humans), some are due to gene expression, some are culturally determined, and some are derived from long-standing or deeply-held beliefs and desires that have solidified into temperament.

Imagine we have six choices for breakfast; a pile of damp and rotting leaves, a bowl of literal faeces, vegemite on toast, a bowl of noodle soup, a bowl of yoghurt, and a bowl of cereal. Based on kingdom-level factors (I am an animals and not a fungus), I don't choose the pile of rotting leaves. Based on species-level factors (I am human and not a dog), I don't choose the faeces. Based on individual genetic differences (I have the AA genotype that corresponds to a preference for sweetness and not the TT genotype for salty foods), I don't choose the Vegemite on toast. Based on cultural factors (I am from NZ and not Vietnam), I don't choose the noodle soup. Based on long-standing / deeply-held beliefs and desires that have solidified into temperament (I am vegan and not an omnivore), I do not choose the yoghurt.
I choose the bowl of cereal

Free will hinges on metaphysical questions – what are the fundamental structures of reality and what is ultimately or basically real? If all that exists is the material parts of the universe – cells, molecules, atoms, sub-atomic particles, and so on all the way up or down – then these constitutive components are always and everywhere and at every level governed by laws of nature, and there seems to be no seat at the table for free will. If in addition to this dominant mode of determinism there might also be forms of indeterminism like randomness or other stochastic processes, still this cannot generate free will as something which is intrinsically determined or decided by and within the subject – still we are not the authors of our actions in any way that flows meaningfully and stably from 'selves' acting spontaneously, self-expressively, with discretion, etc.

If I subscribed to this account of the universe – or to put it more precisely, if this account of the universe as purely deterministic were truly universal, applying no less to human beings as something manifestly distinct within the universe as to everything else which in fact does unfold in a deterministic manner – then I would be committed to incompatibilism and would reject free will. But this account proffered by strict materialism is reductive and cannot yet (and may never) account in a satisfactory way for consciousness, deep ethical realism, mystery and the mystical, and more. You can find robust intellectuals offering an alternative metaphysics (to strict materialism) – they are reasonable, deeply realistic, wise, not reductive in the least, and they are completely open to evolution and everything else which is truly scientific. You can find them especially in the Aristotelian / Thomistic tradition, although more generally you will find the same sort of sanity and capaciousness from within the great Classical tradition which is so much the bedrock of our Western Civilization. (If you're interested I can throw out a few specific thinkers.)

The widespread intuition about free will – the (almost) ineradicable instinct that we are in fact free in at least some of our actions – may be a type of evidence. When taken together with deep structures of society like language and even thought itself, the realism of free will is reflected with remarkable force and consistency across and throughout our experiences, intuitions, institutions, and traditions of thought, diffused and dispersed so immanently as to be almost imperceptible at first. But without the ontological reality of free will, so much as we know it becomes actually unintelligible – until deniers inevitably and unselfconsciously smuggle free-will right back into the conversation! To take the claim seriously is to be more cautions and maybe agnostic about free will until we have more and better evidence, both from empirical science as well as rigorous philosophical thought and the integration thereof. For all you serious thinkers: keep at it!

The bottom line of the problem comes to be how to define free will. You seem to say that free will comes through options, but it shouldn't be taken as given. Rather, we should consider the possibility that our free will is precisely the ability to make choices based on causes and states. If our decisions were random, we would also say that we have no free will, because randomness is out of our control. This is why hard determinism can be seen as a form of free will, but also shows us the problem of defining free will.

In my opinion, we need to think of free will in terms of the law of large numbers in mathematics. Any single event, like a flip of the coin, can be random, but when this event is clustered into large systems of events, as in a society, they are more likely to be determined. When the coin is flipped thousands of times, it is slowly etching its way closer and closer to the 50-50 ratio. Thus, the random event is an individual making a choice to eat oatmeal instead of corn flakes and an example of a large system of clustered events is your personality and/or the interactions with other personalities.

This is a logical fallacy. You can't argue that free will doesn't exist, because you can't explain it's cause. It's begging the question. You're saying:

1. Free Will has no prior cause.
2. Everything must have a prior cause.
3. Free Will does not exist.

But with that logic determinism doesn't work that well either. Because this logic would need endless regression. And we could at least be very skeptical about such an idea.

A single-celled organism doesn't have free will. All it can do is react to external stimuli according to the laws of physics. It cannot, say, choose to ignore Pascal's Principle because it prefers to think that pressure applied to an enclosed incompressible static fluid is NOT transmitted undiminished to all parts of the fluid. It cannot decide that the Superposition Principle doesn't apply to it because total system influence being the sum of individual influences just feels too restrictive. It does not have the freedom to do that. Nothing does.

Now, does it get free will if we add one cell? No. The laws of physics still apply, and the combined state of the two cells at time iteration 2 is always entirely determined by the state of the two cells at time iteration 1, combined with physics. How about if we add two? No. How about if we add 37 trillion and call that collection of cells "human"? Still no. At what point would free will show up? Was is around 10 trillion, or was is not until we added the 37th? As long as the human mind is a product of the brain, and the brain is comprised of physical matter that at all times must adhere to the laws of physics, free will cannot exist.

It makes sense that we aren't sophisticated enough to fully grasp our own thought process. We would need a more sophisticated process to assess our own, which would then be our thought process which we would not be sophisticated enough to grasp... The reality is that reality is deterministic. The implication, however, as far as I'm concerned, is "so what?" Since we aren't sophisticated enough to step outside of the process, the rational thing to do is to proceed with the intuitive sense of free will, despite knowing that it is an illusion. The same applies to our grasp of reality. We know full well that we poorly grasp only a narrow glimpse of what is happening in our immediate vicinity, yet we behave as if we understand our world. It doesn't make sense to adapt a laissez faire attitude just because we realize we can't have total control or total awareness. Predetermined or not, success is less likely without intent. Intent may be predetermined, but as expectations go, we're better off trying to do things. In other words, don't let this sort of thing cause you to lose your ambition. Life is still as meaningful and we are still as free as we feel, for all practical purposes anyway.

Though my body may use chemicals to tell me I'm hungry, i can choose not to eat. Though my body may give me a craving for a specific type of food, i can choose to eat something different. On the other hand, if you are hit by a sudden uncontrollable wave of emotion and act on it, did you have free will? Not entirely, and that's proven. Just like nature vs nurture, the answer to determinism vs free will is yes, they both exist simultaneously, some things are caused by a predisposition for them to happen, while some things happen for the first time and often completely change that deterministic climate, so to speak.

There are arguments supporting Libertarian free will. There is the argument from moral responsibility: (i) to be morally responsible for an action I had to be free to do otherwise when I did it, (ii) we are often morally responsible for our actions, (iii) therefore many of our actions are free. Obviously, there is a lot to discuss there but it is a good prima facie argument.

The second argument is the one you mentioned and that is from experience: (i) If we experience the world such that p is the case, then we ought to believe that p is the case until that belief is defeated by better evidence, (ii) we experience the world such that our actions seem freely performed (i.e. we could have done something very different), (iii) there are no convincing defeaters for the way we experience the world, (iv) therefore we ought to believe that we are free. When you call such experiences "feelings", that strikes me as a poor attempt to discredit them and reinforces (iii) above. There are better challenges to (iii) and so there is much more to discuss about this argument as well.

If an act of the will can exist free from all contingency, then a present act of the will is made an effect caused by a previous act of the will, and that act of the will was an effect caused by a previous, ad infinitum, all the way back to the very first act of the will. But it is impossible for something to be both its own cause and effect. If an act of the will would be its own cause, then in fact it would never happen, because nothing can create itself...

If there is an error in my thinking, please tell me; I'm sincerely trying to figure this out.

I define free will as the ability to chose EITHER of two or more options.  This is not an extraordinary claim, so should not require extraordinary evidence.  I choose a green shirt today; I choose a blue shirt tomorrow.  I feel like I have free will.  And quantum mechanics have put determinism to bed.  
The objections I have heard to free will usually take one of three forms.

1) I don't chose the circumstances of my birth, nationality, genetics, etc.  So what?  I am not claiming omnipotence, or to be able to change my past.  Here I am, and I chose which way to go from here.
2) The brain scan type experiments show that we are not aware when the decision is made.  First, speaking is a more complicated path than moving your arm, so maybe the decision was made significantly before the command to vocalize could reach the mouth?  Secondly, so what?  My arm jerks away from an over burner before I'm aware I'm touching it.  Does my delayed perception mean the pain wasn't real?
3) All my decisions are influenced, often by things I am unaware of.  So what?  If there were no influences, I would never be able to make any decisions, because all options would have equal weight.

Have I missed something?  Have I dismissed something that should not have been dismissed?

how about try to answer a simpler question- what distinguishes humans from animals like tigers when it comes to making choices/decisions related to food? it's relatively easier to answer- a tiger eats deer (assume it only eats deer), which in turn eats grass which in turn grows out of nutrients in the soil and using sunlight. so availability of food for the tiger will depend on the number of deer available (which in turn will depend on the amount of grass available and so on) plus its hunting ability (vs. the deer's escape ability). so overall its actions are deterministic (albeit in a chain of complex links). but what if the tiger thinks- "why not i capture some deer and keep them captive, so i won't have to hunt? what if i gather/grow grass myself so that i can raise more no of deer and so more food will be available?" a tiger is not capable of thinking like this because it doesn't have the tool to use displacement (ie thinking about things which are not present HERE & NOW). but humans have language as a tool which allows them to think using displacements. this way you can say that humans have more freedom than a tiger (because a tiger's actions are largely governed by the environment in which it's living at the time concerned and hence are largely deterministic). this may not be an answer to free will in absolute sense but i think it can explain it in relative sense.

The way I see it, as physical beings we are subject to a physical world and experience it through physical means (i.e. our senses: sight, hearing, touch, taste, smell). This ability to experience reality on the physical level is input into our physical brains which have an ability to process the information, sort it, make sense of it, and store it for later use. It cannot be debated that man is rational, as we can see through our accomplishments as a race that we can intelligently experience physical reality, make sense of it, and use our experience to create new and better things. In other words, we are equipped with the ability to think and use logic, unlike any other animal on earth. We are rational.
When it comes to abstract and metaphysical thinking, however, things get a bit more complicated. While we still experience the physical, we are elevating our physical mental structures and forming logical thoughts on higher subject matter. While I am not outrightly an opponent to naturalistic evolution (this is a subject which can be extensively debated in my opinion), to conclude that such a high level of thinking and mental processes is simply a matter of the evolution of man's body and mind from a primordial species seems to be a bit rash. While evidence may seem to point (to some extent) towards a common ancestry between man and ape, it would seem to me that such a high level of intelligence which goes far beyond man's ability to merely rationalize solely on sensory experience. In other words, man's ability for elevated thought processes seems disconnected from mere physical creation and bespeaks of some sort of higher, intelligent existence.
Now, you might be asking where this is going or how this connects to the subject of free will or determinism. In this way a connection is made: as rational creatures, able to comprehend physical experiences and contemplate higher thoughts and use abstract thinking, a trait dissimilar to any other creature, this seems to lead to the logical conclusion that we are innately born with the ability to judge and discern. What purpose would that ability serve if it means we cannot actually use it? If we are products of evolution without any higher intelligence being involved, is this a flaw in nature? More clearly put, is our natural ability to think and reason essentially worthless, despite the fact that we have it? Of course, one could argue that our ability to reason is really just an illusion, and that since our physical capabilities are contingent on physical reality (such as mental processes), we are essentially predisposed to act a certain way, regardless of our desire to have governance over ourselves. Yet this argument fails in my opinion. Ultimately, a thing is true or it is not. Everything is subject to reality in some way, this concept is the idea of fact. So that the world has its courses and obeisance to natural law, yet it cannot be known for certain exactly in which way it will follow it, even if we can very closely predict its path. A tornado has a million different direction it could go, and we may be able to accurately predict which way it goes. Yet despite this, we are still unable to PROVE or declare with absolute certainty which path it will take. This slight bit of uncertainty is enough to show that objects, while subject to set laws, do not necessarily have to follow any given path. As there is no way to tell for absolute certainty what an object will do or which path it will follow, one cannot say with certainty that it's path was determined. Same for humans. While we may be predictable and predisposed to certain behavior due to biological or genetic influences, our actions are ultimately not physically determined because we cannot claim with absolute certainty what we will do or the exact consequences of our actions. It only seems reasonable, then, to believe that we are definitely in control of what we do, how, and why, despite many influential factors.From a creationist perspective ( I am a creationist, Roman Catholic), it is believed that God foresees our fate, but He ultimately allows our fate to be put in our hands by means of our actions (which are ultimately governed by our reason, intellect, and will).
In sum, I think the idea that we are not ultimately in control of ourselves is a concept set on a very tenuous foundation, and I might even add it is an attempt to excuse ourselves from misdeeds and guilt. This is a subject which does require a bit more in-depth dialectic discussion, but I feel strongly that there is little in the way of substance to support the fundamental views of determinism.

Goedel's incompleteness theorem and chaos both conspire to make nonsense of the idea. There really are no shortcuts here for an external actor to make use of the determinism.
Instead of talking about minds let us discuss rubber ducks in a river. Say you decided that you wanted to dump a rubber duck in a river then predict where it will end up. You measure the condition of the river at the start, you measure the exact point and trajectory that the duck lands in the water. The measurements are precise enough to squeak under the ravages of chaos theory. You feed this into a simulation and determine your result. You then head down to the river for your moment of triumph only to find that a 3 year old has scooped your rubber duck out of the water.
This is the way the world works. Deterministic yet unpredictable. That leaves us with free will being an illusion, but an illusion that is indistinguishable from the real thing.
As far as skipping out on personal responsibility, puhlease. We live in a world that needs at least some rules. The rules must be applied and punishment prescribed for the violators. The rules become part of the brain's programming, they become part of the deterministic system within every mind. In fact the effectiveness of the rules is governed by application of the punishment. Living in a world where no one is held responsible for chainsawing his neighbor to death benefits nobody.

I mean, if you're trying to argue that all actions are predetermined you can't be allowed to get away with saying that 'oh if you look hard enough at the lead up to the event you'll find causes' because now you know what the event was and you're simply looking for anything that could possibly be seen as causing the event. Similar to the 'she hadn't experienced colour even if she knew all about it' issue from a previous video; you're assuming that 'she' found new knowledge of colour when she saw it for the first time and using that in your argument. Also, you're assuming that there are identifiable factors that 'caused' your decision and using that assumption as evidence that factors, that could be argued to be coincidental, are actually causation.
Just my two-cents...

This debate is so old as the thinking mankind itself - and will not lead to an ultimate conclusion for a very simple reason: the reality surrounding us is far more complicated then the grasping capacity of our brain. There are billions of factors which have to be taken under consideration and missing just one of them can lead to a total different conclusion. Our brains tend therefore to construct more simple reality models - especially on the level of the meta-language - and that's why determinism or evolutionism became such popular ideas. The hope, with ratio and with the scientific method we could one day fully understand the world didn't fulfill and the more we know the more questions arise. If we are realy honest with ourself we have to admit, that it is still our believe that things are determined - as well it is still our believe that we have a free will. For myself I believe in a free will. I understand it as an ability of mind to make decisions and to choose between two things. Even in a situation when I am complitely powerless (defeated by a sickness or by another person's force) I can still make a choice: I can accept my fate or not. "Die Gedanken sind frei". The simpliest thought mistake is the following: the fact, that previous events have an impact on my decisions doesn't mean I don't make any decision. A conscious mind which has to decide to go to the right or rather to the left doesn't know the future implications of it's decision. Therfore it tries to get so much help and information from it's past as possible. Also, the decision making involves all parts of the brain - like the subconscieusness, which has an access to the memories currently unavaliable to the ratio.
