Some pseudo-intellectuals have erroneous ideas about fate and destiny and imagine that this doctrine causes stagnation and inactivity, restraining man from all forms of effort to improve his life. The source of this notion in the West is a of adequate understanding of the concept, particularly as it is expounded in Islamic teachings. In the East, it has gained influence because of decline and backwardness.

It is fairly well-known that whenever individuals or historical communities fail to reach its goals and ideals, for whatever reason, they console themselves with words such as 'luck "accident," "destiny," "fate."

The Most Noble Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, expressed himself eloquently on this matter An age will come for the people of my community when they will commit sin and inequity, and in order to justify their corruption and pollution, they will say: 'God's fate and destiny decreed that we act thus.' If you encounter such people, tell them I disown them.

Belief in fate and destiny does not prevent man from striving to reach his goals in life. As those who have the necessary religious knowledge realize, Islam calls on human beings to strive to the utmost in improving their lives, both morally and materially. This is, in itself, a powerful factor in intensifying the efforts man makes.

One of the Western thinkers who has an inadequate understanding of fate and destiny is Jean-Paul Sartre. He imagines it is impossible simultaneously to believe in a fate and destiny determined by God and in the freedom of man, and that it is, therefore, necessary to choose either belief in God or the freedom of man: Because I believe in freedom, I cannot believe in God, because if I believe in God, I will have to accept the concept of fate, and if I accept fate, I will have to renounce freedom. Since I am attached to freedom, I do not believe in God.

However, there is no contradiction between belief in fate, on the one hand, and the freedom of man, on the other. While regarding God's will to be universal in scope, the Noble Qur’an also ascribes a free and active role to man, describing him as capable of consciously fashioning his own destiny with a knowledge of good and bad, ugly and beautiful, and the capacity to choose between them.

We have shown the path to man, and he is free to choose the right path and be thankful or to choose the path of ingratitude. (76:3)

Whoever wishes for the eternal abode and strives for it as needed will find his efforts rewarded. (17:19)

Those who on the Day of Judgment seek refuge in determinism and say:

If God wished, we would not worship other than Him (16:35)

are rebuked for attributing their own sinfulness and error to divine will and fate.

In none of the verses of the Qur’an are the corrupt and evil deeds of individuals or societies attributed to fate and destiny. Equally, fate and destiny are not depicted as obstacles to a corrupt and polluted society's reforming itself. Not a single verse can be found in which God's will has supplanted man's will, or in which it is said that men started to suffer because of fate and destiny.

The Qur’an repeatedly mentions the wrath of God that will overtake the tyrannical and corrupt, bringing painful punishment in its wake.

Since God is extremely loving and merciful to His servants, having bestowed countless bounties on them, and is, at the same time, clement and ready to accept repentance, He always keeps open for the sinner the path of return to purity and rectitude. God's acceptance of repentance is, in itself, a great instance of His mercy.

Although the scope of man's will is greater and more extensive than that of all other known living creatures and plays a more creative role, his will has effect only in areas delimited for his activity and deeds by God. He cannot, therefore, accomplish everything he wants throughout his life.

It often happens that man decides to do something but however hard he tries, he is unable to accomplish it. The reason for this is not that God's will opposes itself to man's will and prevents him from doing what he wishes. It is rather that in such cases some unknown external factor which lies beyond the scope of man's knowledge and control creates obstacles in his way and prevents him from attaining his goals.

Both individuals and societies constantly encounter such obstacles. Considering the fact that in the natural realm there is no cause without an effect and no effect without a cause, and that our means of perception are limited to this world and to the human realm, it should not be difficult for us to accept that our aspirations may not be fulfilled as we desire.

God has set billions of factors to work in the order of being. Sometimes those factors are apparent to man, at other times they remain unknown to him and cannot be incorporated in his calculations. This, too, relates to fate and destiny, but not only does it not result in depriving man of free will or prevent him from striving to attain satisfaction in life; it also guides him in both thought and activity and imbues the very depths of his being with greater vitality. He seeks to augment his knowledge and identify, as precisely as possible, the factors that pave the way for attaining greater success in life. Belief in fate and destiny is then a potent factor in advancing man toward his aims and ideals.

At 6:04, am I the only one seeing the circular reasoning fallacy he is using?

This is the argument presented:
** PREMISE 1: Mental states (and particularly: decisions) are directly tied to the physical reality
** PREMISE 2: All the physical reality is deterministic
** CONCLUSION: Decisions must be deterministic, there's no room for free will in this view

The problem is that the second premise is already assuming the conclusion, the premise is already stating what is supposed to be demonstrated by the argument!

If we were to consider that free will actually exists, then Premise 2 is necessarily wrong, since we would have found an example showing that not everything that is tied to the physical reality is necessarily deterministic.

And since what's being discussed is whether free will exists or not, you cannot just assume what's convenient for your position. The argument presented in the video is a circular reasoning fallacy, it's not a valid argument.

Loved the video, my problem is with the presentation of Libertarian free will position (LFW) I must admit though.Some philosophers present LFW advocates to take the assumption that actions must be uncaused to be free,but that is not true. Aristotle/St.Thomas Aquinas account is more accurate, mainly, that humans are unmoved movers, and first causers of their own actions. Plus, it is not even necessary for an agent to physically act in order to be free. At minimum an agent has to AT LEAST will to do X or refrain from doing X in order to be free. So if someone pushes me down the stairs it is not the case that I need to defy gravity to be free, but to at least will not to fall even though I am subject to physical laws. My acts and wills can be self-caused and directed in virtue of me being an agent. Also, the analysis has nothing to do with my options available but my causal powers as an agent.

Imagine a woman called Sarah is given a time machine. Sarah in her first trip travels into the future but she does not know when. When she arrives, the first thing she sees is a very straight alley with a bar to the right and a pink house in the end of the alley. Sarah decides she is going to investigate the bar to the right. When she looks in into the window, Sarah spots a pair of eyes very similar to hers, there is a Sarah inside the bar ordering a cup of water and while she was waiting she looked into the window to then see her past self. Sarah that is not in the bar just like the other version of herself assumes that that must be herself, but from a different time.
Now, in her second trip, she travels to the past. She lands in a garden property of a new house that's getting painted pink. Sarah approaches the man that's painting it and she's told to get more paint. Unfortunately, the place where Sarah gows to buy the paint has ran out of pink paint and zo Sarah has to buy a lot of yellow paint. So then the house is painted yellow.
Five years later Sarah finds herself very thirsti so she spots a bar in an alley and goes to order water. As she looks into the window she sees herself, her past self, an encounter she had completely forgotten during the five years of time travel. When she had finished the cup of water, she stepped out of the bar and looked at the beautiful house in the end of the alley, a beautiful yellow house.
Right, story time over. In my interpretation of time, I see the future in a superposition, therefore you must get to that specific moment in time for it to lock down into something. In the case of Sarah, seeing herself in the bar accidentally locked that place in time, meaning, that Sarah had to be there in the bar at that time (Unless you want to create different and parallel timelines). Yet the house, even though the young Sarah saw it pink, it's now yellow. That's because when Sarah traveled back in time and changed the color of the house that too was in superposition and it got locked to the fact that the house was yellow. Of course that is all if timetravel was posible. But all this hasnt answered the question, are we free or not? The answer is that if the theory is right, we are free. Since the future can be anything and is everything at the same time depending on what you do while you measure it, a chain of actions of cause to effect (everybody's favorite way of understanding time, except, maybe whovians) is generated by your action, that could have been any other but yet you decided it was that. Conclusion, we have free will unles you travel into the future and see your whole life, then you actions are determined.

There is a difference between determinism and predestination/fatalism, as predestination/fatalism is when someone/something sees into the future and reports what is going to happen (e.g. a prophecy, an oracle). This report of what the prognosticator saw will happen (if clairvoyance/prophecy actually could happen--I personally don't believe in that stuff), will still happen, even if the agent had/has libertarian free will. This is to say that the prophecy would merely be a report of the consequences of an agent with libertarian free will at some point in time. The only way out of that is to say that there are multiple dimensions with different possibilities, enabled by libertarian free will, and that a time traveler is merely choosing one (and will likely be wrong). But that doesn't help Oedipus, unless he got incredibly unlucky, statistically.

I don't know where they got their definition of "hard determinism" but the reason their argument sounds so infallible is because of how they defined that term. The real definition is that all human behaviors and actions are caused by external factors, which is a debatable philosophy. Their definition that "all events are caused by past events such that nothing other than what does occur could occur" is nothing but them playing around with words. An event is "something that happens" or "the outcome or result of a thing." So if we switch the synonyms out (bit of playing around with words myself), their definition actually reads in simpler words: "all of the results of something are cause by the results of something else, and the result of that is that the only things that happen are things that happen."

Or, perhaps it is not free will, but determinism that is the source of retributive justice. For example:

The point of “an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth” is to demonstrate to the offender the harm that they have inflicted on someone else. The point of this type of penalty is (a) to provide a deterrence to those considering inflicting harm on others (because they will reap the same harm upon themselves) and (b) to teach the person what it is like to be on the receiving end. This is deterministic causation, a penalty designed to reduce harm within the community.

We can also see determinism justifying the presumption that a small harm can justify a much harsher penalty. The penalties are listed. When the offender deterministically causes the crime he also causes the penalty.

Ironically, many Christian leaders and organizations have been at the forefront of prison reform and as advocates of rehabilitation. And they generally believe in free will. One other thing they believe in is “redemption” (rehabilitation) of even the worst sinner.

So free will is getting a bum rap. After all, there is no such thing as rehabilitation without the notion of a person who can be redeemed through counseling, drug treatment, education, job training, post-release follow-up, and other rehabilitation programs. The goal of rehabilitation is a person who can autonomously make better choices in the future. And free will is a synonym of autonomy.

How confusing is this? Determinism is a conceptual model we use to understand how things work. We want to do that because we want to influence or even change how things work. Why? We want them to work better for us. But determinism demands that we desire this as part of a necessary causal chain that began before we were born. How we want things to change is just as determined as the existing state of affairs. If we realize this in a desperate moment of panic and try to change directions, we panic again in the realization that this too has been determined. In fact, anything that we do avoid the what prior conditions have deemed to be inevitable will simply prove how determined we really are. There is only one thing we can do to avoid becoming a minor cog in the great universal machine.

What's that? We live in an empirical world. We use models to help explain and manage that world. But the models are never the same as that real world. At best, they are useful oversimplifications of reality. Often, they are simply distortions. When we deceive ourselves that our models are the reality, we walk into a prison and toss away the key. Rather than using our models to achieve objectives, we rely upon our models to tell us what is real. But models can only reflect an image of reality. The history of science teaches us that quite often our models don't even do that terribly well. They may be useful to a point but not totally reliable. Though a globe might be useful to understand something of the earth's geography, no one would confuse it with the real thing.

That may seem too obvious, but our concepts are like that globe. Determinism and libertarian free will are simply conceptual models of reality. When our concepts begin tying us into knots, we should relax for a moment. We created our conceptual models. It is the physical reality that we did not create, despite what the solipsists among us might say. When our thoughts about the real world--that is, our conceptions of it--give us indigestion and an existential crisis, it's not the real world we should be worrying about. Our conceptual thinking is probably the culprit. It is always a mistake to sacrifice the real world as an act of worship to our ideas. As human beings, we have a tendency to do that. What we need, however, are better ideas. Adopting a new conceptual model can sometimes be one of the healthiest things we can do.

"Fate" in the sense of the Oedipus prophesy does not actually exist.  There is no magic oracle which can see the future and accurately predict our future actions.  First, the assumption that the universe is 100% deterministic is unproven. The universe may instead be probabilistic.  But more to the point, the mere fact that the universe is deterministic IN THEORY does not mean that the future can be predicted IN PRACTICE.  Just look at the weather forecast for 10 days from now, and see how may times they change that before the day actually arrives.  When you are talking about a complex CHAOTIC system like weather or the human brain, there are many "butterfly effects" which can alter the outcome of the future.  And in order to make an accurate prediction, one would need to measure the exact state of the human brain, and current scientific theory is that it is impossible to measure something precisely without influencing it... the act of predicting our future actions would change the future and render the prediction invalid.

Determinism is exceptionally easy to refute.

If determinism is true, then we are simply determined to believe what we believe -- including our beliefs regarding determinism.

This means that there is no way to know if my beliefs are wrong, if I am simply determined to believe in them -- including my belief about determinism. This means there is no reason, then, to believe in determinism.

It would also mean that knowledge is impossible. But the truth-claim that knowledge is impossible is a knowledge-claim about the nature of knowledge (that it is impossible). Therefore this is a self-refuting statement.

If that statement is self-refuting, it cannot be possible. If it cannot be possible, then determinism is false.

The only recourse is some form of free-will.

(Disclaimer: I'm a 1st year philosophy student and am regurgitating ideas that are categorically not my own - if anything, what I've written below is really just an exercise to help me see how well I understand the content in my lectures)

Can I take issue with one of the final comments here? The idea that determinism is the lens through which we might understand how and why Oedipus came to murder his father and marry his mother is problematic - and to a degree misrepresents determinism. The story of Oedipus is better explained by fatalism - an idea that appears similar to determinism at first, but a fundamental distinction can be made between the two - determinism says a specific event in the present will generate a specific event in the future, i.e. what happens in the future is governed by the present - fatalism says a particular event in the future is fixed - cast in stone - regardless of what happens in the present, i.e. what happens in the present is governed by the future, in a sense - comments, anyone?

It seems to me that the debate between libertarian free will and determinism must come down to whether or not agent causation is unprescribed and the only way for agent causation to be unprescribed is whether or not dualism-interactionism is true. So although the brain has direct physical interactions with the physical world, the mind (or soul) - which is not within the physical world - is the operator behind the decision. As an analogy, a pianist would be the mind and the piano would be the brain. The pianist chooses the music he wants to play and the piano responds with music. The piano cannot produce music without the pianist and the pianist cannot conduct music unless he has a piano and hears sound emanating from it so that he may continue.

Now of course, if you're not a dualist-interactionist then forget everything and determinism is true. But if the mind does exist separate - although not independent - from the brain, then it is highly plausible that agent causation can be unprescribed and, therefore, libertarian free will is true. So I think it really boils down to your belief in naturalism vs. supernaturalism. A naturalist will deny dualism-interactionism and be deterministic based on materialism while some theists will accept dualism-interactionism and be libertarians based on supernaturalism. Any thoughts?

Dear Hank,

You are wrong in 3 ways:

1) We CANNOT know that there is a CAUSATION between neural states/brain states and mind states. All that we see is a correlation, and under physicalism (a hidden paradigmatic assumption), we perceive it to be causation. It is not, that is just a belief.
2) From 1 it stems that we cannot know whether the mind is based on a physical, deterministic substrate or not. Thus, free will is not at odds with the deterministic mechanisms.
3) Last but not least, there are things not deterministic even in our mainstream metaphysical paradigm - quantum mechanics.
The position of a particle up until it is observed is determined by its wavefunction. And when an observer observes the particle's actual position, it is fundamentally random within that field of probability. No hard determinism there.

So, there are at least 2 ways in which hard determinism is wrong and thus there is no contradiction between free will and determinism.

A small comment on Determinism:
Quantum physics predicts that determinism is false, there's inherent randomness to the universe (not complete randomness, some events are more likely than others, we call this a non-uniform random distribution).

This property of nature is actually necessary for stuff to happen, it's sort of what makes things not do nothing...

Some people like to defend "free choice" in these quantum fluctuations.

Others accept the fact that there's undeterminism, but there' isn't real free choice anyway, since it's like flipping a coin and deciding that we made that decision based on the fact that we flipped the coin. Such "free will" would be in individual atoms as well?

This is "Hard Undeterminism", we might not predict exactly what's going to happen, but there's still no free will...

Finally, there's no way to actually know how much the randomness really affects our overall behaviour. Perhaps something up to 90% of our behaviour is predictable by classical physics, and we only need quantum collapses to explain some occasional 10% or something less.

Soft Determinism simply redefine "free will" as the things your brain does to make a decision within physics. It's a way of have compatibility, but it is not the same sense of free will, and the determinism part is most certainly false.
Hard determinism leads to an infinite regress of past of events, though. Which in turn leads to logical absurdities.
So... if everything is predetermined... then how can we hold anyone accountable by their deeds? (just like he says at ~9:05)

No one can ever prove one theory or the other, unless we can see the future and them go back in time and see if we ended up doing it as it was supposed to happen (deterministic view) or if we chose to do something different (free will view).
Even if we got an "universal equation" that could compute the future, that equation itself would be ruled by the same laws it computed. If so, using energy to compute that equation, would cause the results to differ from the calculated future, because energy would have to be used to run it (and you can't use energy and at the same time compute itself being used).
Either we would have to be in another universe to use such an equation (and run it with energy from another universe, not affected by that equation) or running the equation would mean that the results would be useless, rendering the "universal equation" not universal at all.

But if such universe can exist, why can't it be the one we currently live in?

The fact that you can explain why one chose an option rather than the others doesn't mean it was determined.

You could give an explanation for his/her decision, regardless of what it happens to be; it'd just have to be a different explanation for each different choice. I'll try to give you an example. Jane is about to have a snack, he can have an apple, a pear, or a chocolate bar. Her favourite fruit is the apple, and she has an overall healthy lifestyle. If she was to choose the apple, the reasons why she did so is that she just loves apple and that she knows apples are healthy. If she was to choose the pear, we'd say that she loves apples, but she's had some recently, so she wanted a change and chose the healthiest between the two remaining options. If, on the other hand, she went for the chocolate bar, maybe she did so because she has an overall healthy lifestyle, so she thought she could allow herself to have a tasty sugary snack, nothing bad will come out of it. It's likely that she considered all these factors, whatever her choice was.

I need to think about this more, but if beliefs and such in our minds determine our actions (which makes sense), what determined those beliefs? Were they not choices/ calculated evaluations? I don't know if determinism addresses this, but it was not mentioned in this overview. I imagine they might say that the beliefs are determined by what you are exposed to and by logic and reasoning. It is evident that each person thinks differently, so logic and reasoning are not exactly determined generally. But, the circumstances of your birth (who your family is, where you live, what/how you are taught in school, etc) determine what you are exposed to and how you develop your sense of logic and reasoning.
I had ham and cheese for lunch because I bought ham and cheese at the store. I bought ham and cheese at the store because being cheap and quick to prepare, it is perfect for a student. Reasoning. Why might I choose something different? Price? Change in status (no longer a student = more time to cook)? So, if something else where cheaper but also relatively healthy and easier to prepare, I might buy it instead. But that comes down to an outside event (setting the price), not to a change in my decision/decision factors.
I've thus taken what Hank said and framed it thus: the beliefs and tendencies in my mind are like formulas, and the outside events are like variables which, when plugged into these formulas, produce an outcome, which is by extension, pre-determined by the formula.
Looked at this way, Determinism doesn't exactly mean that you don't make choices. It means the choices that you make aren't entirely, individually, free, but are instead governed by set rules inside of you and outside of you. Those rules can sometimes change. Being exposed to new information can change your beliefs. Whether you're exposed to new information can be determined, for example, by whether you step out of your comfort zone.
The point that my thinking through this here makes is that this does not necessarily mean that everything is set in stone (like the Oedipus prophecy example), but simply that everything happens for/ can be traced back to specific reasons. It makes sense that, all factors the same, you would not have made a different choice, because clearly you used your same reasoning and faculties to make the choice that you did. Hank, for example, could absolutely have chosen to eat cream of wheat; nothing prevented him from doing so. Would have, clearly not. But the way he explained it, Determinists think he Could not have, and there's no real basis for that.

Problems for Hard Determinism(HD):
Latent Substance Dualism- HD as a scientifically based position rejects non-physical causes. Experiments which observe brain (the organ that does the deciding) activity to "determine the decision the agent is going to make" is a misnomer. The observations are of the decision being made by the physical agent. It's only through latent belief of the subjectively experienced "output" (mind) as a separate entity from the physical agent that any illusion of determinacy occurs.

Indeterminacy- the base state of physics is probabilistic, not determinate. While classical and relativistic scale systems often are determinate, there are some examples of classical indeterminacy. Moreover, the assertion that the most complex system known to humans (brains) has no quantum components to its decision making processes is unjustified.

Pseudoscience: once freed of latent substance dualism all experiments regarding HD in agents (Libet, Haynes, etc) are using the past to explain the present at best, if not just making observations about the present independent of anything else. No "risky predictions" are made. Claims that agents "couldn't have made any other decision" are unfalsifiable.

The question I ask people when debating this topic is:

Do you control your mind, or does your mind control you?

If you choose the former, then:
- What is this "you" that can control your mind?  This "thing" must exist external to your mind and body, otherwise it is just a part of your existing mind, in which case, skip to option 2.
- You believe there is some force or power outside of "your self" that can control something inside of you - your mind
- You believe there is something more than the 4 fundamental forces that can control biological systems, like your brain
- There are no physical mechanisms that can explain what this power or force is
- Therefore, you believe in either magic or some higher power or deity to provide this free will capability and resolve this paradox

If you choose the latter, then you have to accept that:
- Your actions are controlled by the state of your mind at any particular moment
- Your brain is a (very complex) biological system
- A biological system is a physical system
- All physical systems we know of are controlled by the 4 fundamental forces of nature
- The state of any physical system at any one time can be predicted from it's prior state and the forces acting upon it
- The current state of your brain, and all past and future states can in turn be likewise predicted
- Therefore, you are a determinist

[No, quantum indeterminacy DOES NOT give us free will, it only removes the "clock-work" nature of the universe.  And if you believe there is some part of "you" that can control quantum states, then go back and proceed with option 1.]

I don't think it's that hard to refute hard determinism. First, accept the dilemma that either hard determinism or libertarian free will. This video made a case for rejecting the latter but didn't give any evidence in favor of the former--it just explained and boldly offered to accept the implications. But first, take our subjective experience as actual data that needs to be accounted for and not simply explained away. Second, how do we deal with the problem with a deterministic physical universe? Simple. We deny that premise. Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle isn't describing an epistemological problem but rather is getting at an ontological description of the fundamental nature of reality. That is, the physical universe is fundamentally indeterministic. The reason we can so accurately predict causes and effects with fine precision on the large scale is that, when you start adding physical particles together, you get narrower and narrower fields of probability to work with. So, while it is possible that when I light a match all of the molecules could move in just such a way that the match would freeze, the chances are so astronomically small (about 1 in 10^80, I think) that it's practically impossible.

Anyway, the point here is that it is just false that the physical universe is fundamentally deterministic. At the smallest levels we can most clearly see this. A may cause B or it may case C. We simply don't know, nor can we, because there is literally no cause for it being B or C. Sometimes it is B and sometimes it is C. Now, if B, then it was caused by A. Or if C, it was caused by B. But the B or C is itself indeterminate (even if we can weight the probability of one against another with relative accuracy). All that fits very nicely with an Aritotelian notion of teleology, which really fits well with the entire scientific enterprise today, anyway.

Given all that, we actually can propose agent causality to be a real thing. The will is that which determines B or C in an indeterministic manner. Some factors (beliefs + desire + temperament) may weight one outcome as more likely than another, but in the end, the will is indeterminately related to B and C, and which it chooses really free.

Now, to be clear, you can still have this whole view without agent causality. You can propose that the choice is finally random within those probabilities, but what is the motivating premise for accepting that? Seems an implicit commitment to an outdated Newtonian, mechanistic view of the world already undermined by both the premise that the universe is fundamentally indeterministic on the one hand and our subjective data on the other. So better to allow for agent causality. Even grant that agent causality is an emergent property of some sort somehow related to the Uncertainty Principle (which could be argued to take the observer as an actual cause). Science is still out on that. Or take the Aristotelian notion of the soul as an explanatory mechanism. Point is, there are options here, and we don't have to be hard determinists.

The evidence Hank gives for determinism in this video is very hard to refute—indeed, the very fact that I (or at least the conceptual identity that has arisen from various physical and biological processes within my brain to develop into such an idea as "I" and "me") see the necessity in responding to it is probably determined in itself. However, there are also a couple of arguments in refutation that I think are necessary to raise here. There are two big arguments, so I will lay them out below. However, I also doubt that these arguments have any sort of ability to actually refute the larger argument that determinism is true.

First, the argument from consciousness of determinism. If determinism is true, and as we have seen in this video it is very likely that it is, then that means that our very understanding of determinism as being true, and whatever neurological and physical reactions are occurring within the brain to create this sense of knowing that determinism is true, was predetermined to occur. We were meant to understand that everything has a cause as everything is the effect of some cause or other, and every cause or other is in effect the result of the original causation to the universe, the big bang. But this also means that the universe resulted in such a way that it was meant to understand itself from the very beginning. Indeed, whatever physical and biological processes within the brain occur to create this sensation of consciousness and knowing, are also reducible to atomic and quantum terms. So on an atomic level, the universe is all the same to some degree or other. But given that the human brain has the ability to conceptualize self-awareness and self-identity, does this mean that the universe itself is self-identifying and self-aware on an atomic level? Because when a human brain studies an atom and understands that an atom is composed of neutrons, protons, and electrons, well, this also means that atoms are studying themselves... understanding themselves... and that simply doesn't seem to make sense. (Note the use of the verb "seem," implying uncertainty.) So, extrapolating this sense of understanding and knowing from the fact that atoms do indeed seem to understand themselves, we can also assume logically that whatever cognitive processes happen to create the sensation of understanding what determinism is were predetermined to happen. All in all, this seems to mean that the universe itself was made to understand itself. But why? Maybe God made it and intended for us to understand the universe... or maybe the universe itself is conscious, one massive entity composed of smaller constituent beings with a sense of awareness.

However, it has also been posited by many physicists that the universe isn't very predetermined. Hank alludes to the scientific assumption that every effect has a causation, and that each causation itself can be reduced to being an effect of some other cause, on and on and on, until the original causation, the big bang, which should itself be the effect of some other cause. On a quantum level, electrons exist at different locations or velocities—but never simultaneously. We cannot observe without first breaking down the very thing being observed, and so what should be doubted here is the credibility of the claim that everything has a cause. Perhaps it is our understanding of cause and effect that should be revised, and not this argument of whether we are "free" or not. Indeed, quantum entanglement—or as Einstein dubbed it, "Spooky action at a distance"—has been verified experimentally to show that particles on a quantum level have effect on each other at extremely large distances, which does not seem possible of itself. This seems to violate the principle of local realism, the theory that posits values exist objectively and independently of observers before the act of observation, and that all causation occurs at the speed of light. However, we have proven through scientific experiment that Einstein was wrong at least in one sense: the speed of light may be slowed, and therefore information may move at a rate faster than the speed of light. It appears that our understanding of causation and effect may be a bit flawed, then.

Any reaction to determinism should address these concepts, then, i.e. those of causation and effect. Determinists argue that all physical states have a physical cause, as these states are themselves physical effects, but are they right in assuming this? Science has assumed that every piece of information we process subjectively as knowledge is the effect of some cause or other, as indeed the very cause of our visual interpretation of information is based entirely on the fact that what we observe is the radiating light from the original cause, the big bang. But if information can move faster than the speed of light, there may exist certain values or qualities that we are not capable of observing and therefore cannot know about. Therefore, in conclusion, I think that what we must first do is clarify whether cause and effect do actually exist—or, as Hume would suppose, whether they are merely illusions based on our past experience of the world.

There is a limit to determinism in the physical world, namely the uncertainty principle. Consider a case in which a metal ball bearing, floating freely in space, does or doesn't pass through a ring an inch wide that is initially stationary with respect to the ball bearing, with its open side facing the ball bearing...and, say, 1000 meters away. Along comes a second ball bearing that collides with the first one in just the right way to send the first ball bearing moving toward that ring. If the angle of the collision is exactly right, then the 1st ball bearing, after being smacked by the 2nd ball bearing, will pass through the ring.

If the collision happens just a tiny, tiny bit wrong, the 1st ball bearing will not go through the ring.

The uncertainty principle enables multiple outcomes even when there are no changes at all in the approach of the 2nd ball bearing to the 1st ball bearing. What ends up happening with regard to the passage of the 1st ball bearing through or past that ring is a matter of probability. AFTER it has happened, you know what happened. BEFORE it happens, you don't know what will happen.

You could even make the thought experiment more interesting by having lots of rings (all of them a kilometer away from the initially stationary first ball bearing), and keep repeating the experiment, with the approach of the 2nd ball bearing to the 1st ball bearing identical in all trials, and record which of those rings was graced by having the 1st ball bearing pass through it in each trial. It won't be the same ring every time.

Likewise, in a living thing, the uncertainty principle might enable different choices to be made by the same person in the same circumstances. After his choice is made, you know. Before he makes it, you don't know how he will choose. And there's your free will.

A few points.

"Reductionism" in science isn't exactly as he described its use in philosophy. In science it means a change to a lower level of analysis. It was William James who put it best. (I'm probably misquoting because it's been a long time.) Reductionism would reduce a Beethoven string quartet to the scrapings of horse hair across some wires. Well -- yeah. You lose the music but you get harmonics.

A lot of us believe in free will for a couple of reasons. One is that when we make a difficult choice we're exceedingly aware of the struggle going on inside our heads. It certainly FEELS like we're making an important choice.

This leads to what psychologists call "the fundamental error of attribution." We KNOW that we've had to make a choice, but since we're unable to get inside the head of anybody else, it seems to us that he's acting that way just because that's the way he IS. Or, in short, we do what we do because we've decided to do it. He does what he does because it's in his nature to do it. We may cheat because we've decided that it's the best (or only) possible choice for us. He cheats because he's bad.

I won't go on, except to say that the belief in free will is bound up with our belief in an omnipotent god. How can God allow evil to exist? He allows it to exist because he's giving us a test -- which may lead to salvation -- to see if we're good enough. God isn't causin the evil. We are -- to the extent that we're flunking the test.

At 4:39 he changes the definition of Libertarian free will. He turns around and asks us to give an explanation of the explanation. "If you can explain what would cause an agent to act, then you have just reinforced that actions are caused rather than free."

Remember that in his earlier definition he said they are caused by the mind. Now he claims that if we give any causal definition then by definition they are not free. Opps.

This is an equivocation.

Libertarian free will is not absent of causes!!!!

Its causal chain is not predetermined by forces outside the subject.

If a mind uses rationality to choose between multiple actions then we have libertarian free will.

Equivocal definitions is common to this subject-area, however they usually occur when discussing compatibilism, not two different definitions of libertarianism in just a couple of minutes.

Further, in science explanation is inductive. It looks at the data and asks, "Which inference best explains those data?" It doesn't ask, "Could you give me and explanation of the explanation?" Or, "How about and explanation of the explanation of the explanation?"

It quickly kills science all-together due to an infinite regress.

Science doesn't look to get to explanations in one giant leap. Rather, it takes one careful small step at a time.

Quantum physics has demolished the notion that the physical world is exclusively deterministic. On a macro-scale, Newtonian physics can predict things pretty well, but quantum fluctuations make it impossible to predict exactly what's going to happen to every particle always. Perhaps the principle of quantum fluctuation and the ultimate unknowability of what's going to happen in the physical world are precisely the origin of free well. Perhaps our thoughts and actions are governed by probabilities, and somehow human neurons have harnessed the output quantum fluctuations to make "free will" decisions. Certainly this view is supported by the empirical data of human decisions collected by economists . While impossible to determine whether an individual human will purchase an iPhone, it is very possible to determine the probability you will purchase an iPhone given your age, socioeconomic status, race, gender, geographic location, etc... Given a large enough sample size (i.e. the population of America), the sum of all decisions that are free will and probabilistic to an individual, such as going out and purchasing an iPhone, are extremely well predicted on the macro-scale, just as the parabolic motion of a massive collection of particles combined to form a baseball is extremely well predicted by Newtonian mechanics, but the precise location and velocity of an electron in the 234,650,193,245th carbon atom in that baseball is ultimately unknowable.

The funny thing though is that any argument in favor of determinism relies on the arguer's belief that the listener has the free will to change their mind in response to logical persuasion (otherwise the argument is made in bad faith). Anyone with a sincere belief in hard determinism would have the decency to shut up about it.

Inaccuracy at 6:08: The argument that the physical world is strictly deterministic was good before we knew about quantum mechanics. To this day different interpretations of quantum mechanics exist next to each other, that don't agree on this issue.
Quantum mechanics is essentially a theory of probability. As an example: If you role a die, you won't know what the outcome will be. But because of statistics, you roughly know what you'll get when rolling it a million times.
Similarly in quantum mechanics, we get results that seem random, but have a statistical connection. To this day we don't know if quantum events are deterministic or not. And because reality (as far as we know) is basically a bunch of quantum events, this makes matters a bit more complicated. This doesn't imply that you have agency over your own actions, but it questions whether the world in itself really is optionless.

"Freedom does not consist in any dreamt-of independence from natural laws, but in the knowledge of these laws, and in the possibility this gives of systematically making them work towards definite ends. This holds good in relation both to the laws of external nature and to those which govern the bodily and mental existence of men themselves — two classes of laws which we can separate from each other at most only in thought but not in reality. precisely by this that it is not free, that it is controlled by the very object it should itself control. Freedom therefore consists in the

A couple of things in this video are wrong.
Firstly Oediopus is a bad example of determinism - determinism is not fatalism. In the Oedipus example, he presumably actually has a fair amount of free will, only no matter what he does, he will end up killing his father and marrying his mother. In other words, no matter what course of action he chose to take, it would end up with those two events. However this is not an example of being determined, as there were still different courses of action for Oedipus to choose from. In order for it to be an example of determinism, any kind of choice has to be an illusion, and this does not seem to be the case in the Oedipus example.
Secondly, you say that the view that every event has a cause, or that every event that happens now is the necessary result of events in the past, is called hard determinism. Actually, this view is merely called 'determinism'. Whether the determinism is hard or soft depends on whether it holds that determinism is or isn't compatible with free will.

But we can disprove that even with the story of Adam and Eve. Eve had no choice but to eat the forbidden fruit, because she was never told about the concept of the defiance of a command. When the serpent told her to eat it, she wasn't going to defy it, because the concept of a lie was never told to her. Well determinism & free will are just the two sides of the same coin - in a fashion that somewhat resembles wave-particle duality.
Everything is deterministic (adding quantum woo, just adds an unknown element to the causality chain, it doesn't give you more agency), but free will exists to some degree.
Humans (or any other non omniscient beings - if such is possible) make decisions based on incomplete information. This leads to the fact that we are unable to predict future, and we see it as something that can be changed to our will. From there its not that long of a leap of logic to conclude, that since the past 2 seconds were future if we go back 5 seconds in time, all actions we take must have agency.
Sadly they don't, but decision making based on limited information, gives (the very useful) delusion of free will.

I came to this conclusion in my teens or so when I was thinking about my dice. I was also thinking about that episode of Star Trek TNG where Data cheats at gambling by tossing the dice in a way to get the result he wanted.

This made me think that the idea of "random" is a bit of a fallacy. "Random" really means "observers lack the ability to predict the result". And given that everything seems to be caused by something else, if you could perfectly know the state of everything, then everything could be predicted and nothing would actually be random, which is, in the end, the same as determinism.

This bothered me because it suggested that I didn't have free-will. I'm someone who prides myself on the identity I deliberately cultivated. However, if nothing can be truly random, then this pride is for nothing.

I considered the idea that consciousness can introduce randomness to the physical world, but I was unsatisfied with this idea since the mind is made of physical things.

The only way this could work is if the mind was more than physical-- that, perhaps, if we had souls, then that could introduce interrupt the determinism of the universe. However, I just can't believe in the concept of a soul.

Currently, my hope for a non-deterministic universe is in the behavior of matter on a quantum level. That the probability of states of stuff on the quantum level introduces true randomness into the universe.

As I see it, the main point against determinism is that the decision when it's being made and the decision after it was made and implemented are two different things. As Popper said, we can come up with a reasonable explanation to anything. Hence, even if we can build the causational chain all way up, that doesn't mean it's true. My conclusion is that in the first case the decision is at least not as pre-determined as in the second one. Given that, the part that's not pre-determined can be explained by either random, or free will, or a mixture of both, or by something that I'm missing.

I'll just leave this little Reductio ad Absurdum argument from the Objectivism for Intellectuals blog, see if it rings a bell;

P1: If I know that the statement “Preexisting
physical factors necessitate my decision to believe in the content of my
supposed knowledge,” is true, then I possess some actual knowledge.
P2: If I possess some actual knowledge, then I believe in the content of my supposed knowledge because this content is true.
C1: Therefore, if I do not believe in the content of my supposed knowledge because this content is true, then I do not possess this content as knowledge.  [Contrapositive of P2.]
P3: If I know that the statement “Preexisting
physical factors necessitate my decision to believe in the content of my
supposed knowledge,” is true, then I believe in the content of my
supposed knowledge because preexisting physical factors necessitate my
decision to believe in this content.  [Application of definition of
determinism.]
P4: The content of my supposed knowledge being true is not
equivalent to the content of my supposed knowledge being necessitated
by preexisting physical factors. [Under determinism, false beliefs can
be necessitated by physical factors.]
C2: Therefore, if I believe in the content of my
supposed knowledge because preexisting physical factors necessitate my
decision to believe in this content, then I do not believe in the content of my supposed knowledge because this content is true.  [From P4 and identity of “belief because.”]
C3: Therefore, if I know that the statement
“Preexisting physical factors necessitate my decision to believe in the
content of my supposed knowledge,” is true, then I do not believe in the content of my supposed knowledge because this content is true.  [From P3 and C2.]
C4: Therefore, if I know that the statement
“Preexisting physical factors necessitate my decision to believe in the
content of my supposed knowledge,” is true, then I do not possess the
content of my supposed knowledge as actual knowledge.  [From C3 and C1.]
C5: Therefore, if I know that the statement
“Preexisting physical factors necessitate my decision to believe in the
content of my supposed knowledge,” is true, then I possess some content
as actual knowledge and I do not possess any content as actual
knowledge.  [From P1 and C4.]
Reductio ad absurdum of “knowledge of the
truth” of the statement - “Preexisting physical factors necessitate my
decision to believe in the content of my supposed knowledge.”
C6: Therefore, the statement that “I know that
preexisting physical factors necessitate my decision to believe in the
content of my supposed knowledge,” is false.
QED

Libertarianism and hard determinism is not the only two points of view, you only looked at the incompatiblistic side of the isue, that is those that claim that free will is not compatible with determinism, both libertarians and hard determinists hold this view. But there are at least two other philosophical schools on the matter, compatibalists and contrastivists. The compatibalists think that free will means that you are free if you are not hindered from doing what you want to do by your circumstances. With this definition of free will it doesn't matter if your will is determined. The contrastivism are more in to the semantics of the word free. They mean that there are some relevant barrier that we need to get rid of in order to be free, for the incompatibilist causality is that barrier, for the compatibalist limited actions is the barrier.

Most of the philosophy crash course episodes are fairly unbiased, but this one is so horribly skewed in one direction that its educational value is next to none. The video only offers one argument from the Libertarian view (and one of the weaker ones) then goes on for the rest of the episode about how determinism is rock-solid science and there are no valid counterarguments to it. This is why I don't think "free-will should be defined as non-determinism. It should be defined as determined by the person in question. If the person has free-will than the actions and choices of that person are determined by the mind of that person. How it was determined doesn't matter, as long as it was determined by the mind. What the mind is, is also little relevant. If the soul is the mind and the soul determines the actions and choices, the person has free will. If the brain is the mind and the brain determines the actions and choices, the person has free will.

It is also possible that the structure of cause and effect isn't an entirely accurate representation of what is really going on, but only a tool we have for mapping out sequences of events. To say that the world is determined can only be an induction, and it would be really difficult, if not impossible, to actually prove that cause and effect are intrinsic elements of reality. This would imply that the dichotomy of freedom vs determinism may both be reliant on questionable assumptions, and that we ought to think about the problem in new ways.

Steven Pinker deals with the determinism free will like this: Even if we don't have free will (in the libertarian meaning), the concept is so adhesive in our society that we can redefine free will to make it compatible with determinism. I'll explain how this isn't a facsimile of the contradiction Mr. Green gave at the beginning of a video.

Imagine Jeffery Dahmer, the Milwaukee serial killer who raped, ate, and crudely lobotomized young men as a hobby hoping to create a mindless sex slaves. Even if he was "wired wrong," in the sense that he couldn't have done otherwise, we can still imprison him because freeing murderers shouldn't logically follow a lack of free will. Because Dahmer couldn't have done otherwise, we have an obligation to lock him in a cage, not because he could have chosen differently, but because we do not yearn for severed limbs in our neighbor's freezer.

The same logic augments other important ethical problems: Contracts, Crime, Relationships, etc. Even if our lives are determined, effort, deterrents, and incentives still matter in our lives.

Also, as a short note, Determinism is often confused with fatalism; that is, everything is just going to happen regardless of what you do (the chips will fall where they will). Determinism needn't be so dreary. If you want to learn a language or climb a mountain, then the action consists on effort and focus. So stating, "Maybe someday I'll climb Everest, but I'll just let the chips fly," still doesn't make sense in a deterministic universe.

Consider this:

Determinism suggests that we're basically just a bunch of run-away chain reactions interacting with all the other run-away chain reactions, clashing and meshing and tangled up together on every possible scale. We're the experiment in the beaker, our every perception a result of countless factors, big and small, countless and infinite in number, that forced us to arrive at the very state we are in right now.

But I challenge you to imagine being able to perfectly and unmistakable trace every possible action and chain reaction back to its source, as far back as it would take to when (if?) the first reaction to begin all reactions occurred. Now, imagine wiping the entirety of all of existence completely blank, save the absolute, core components of that chain reaction. Finally, imagine that you begin that reaction anew, yourself, exactly as it had began the first time with absolutely no chance of deviation, and you watch it form and grow into whatever it will on its own across however long it may take.

Would the entire universe be identical to the way it is now?

Because if there is even a single variation -- from the smallest scale to the largest, even from perspective, to ideal, to concept, to any other possible distinction -- then the determinism must yield to the possibility of free will, because there will exist the possibility of true randomness and through that, anything can happen without determinism to guide it.

I think that the answer to this question -- a question we will likely never answer -- is the true answer to whether or not we have free will.

(For a real brain bender, in the hypothetically situation above, ask yourself what the first action was; the action you've traced it to, or your decision to initiate it at all. Was that decision deterministic? Or was it free will?)

I think we have free will. Here's why.

It's a matter of deciding after the fact that each thing we chose, because it's in relation to our surroundings, must have been caused by our surroundings.

For example, I'm a mental health specialist, and I have today off from work. But consider if I were to just "decide" to get up right now and go to work without even getting my work clothes on. Lets consider for a moment that this decision is entirely my own, based on free will, and not based on environment or circumstance. Now, this decision would not make sense... because sensible decisions that work are made in relation to environment and circumstance (going to work when it's time to go to work), and hence you could then look at that and say the decision was caused by them. It actually wasn't - the decision was made in relation to them.

Moreover, the items mentioned that create our decisions -- belief, desire, and temperament -- are part of who we are. The thing that is "you" is a combination of those things, so it makes perfect sense that "you" (a collection of these and other things) is making the decision -- that's the very definition of free will.

Your beliefs, desire, and temperament change all the time, because you are not a fixed thing that never changes -- this also wouldn't work in a world where everything around you is also changing. Of course you would also need the ability to change with it (as Bruce Lee might have said, "become like water"). This ability to change doesn't make you any less you. You're still making the decisions. If you had grown up in a completely different country, in a completely different time, then "you" (beliefs, desire, temperament, and others) would simply be different, and hence, you would be making different decisions because you are a different person - but it's still you making the choice.

Choice, under determinism, is not about the existence of alternative possibilities, but instead about the relevance of
components of the self. Deterministic choice occurs when the self is a factor in how events transpire. If Hank shoves oatmeal down my throat there exists much less choice than when my hunger drives me to eat oatmeal. One is caused by factors intrinsic to me, while another is caused primarily by external factors. Perhaps choice isn't the best word to describe the difference between these two scenarios, but I think that it is an important distinction.

If determinism be true, how could we verify it being true? Would not our conclusions likewise be determined? And need there be any reason for our conclusions to reflect reality? Since this is an impossible question, it seems that the only quality answer (be it right or wrong) is the assumption that we do have free will. If we are wrong, then it was deterministically so. If we are right, we are right because we freely agreed with what is true.

Hard Determinism operates on the assumption that the world is hard-deterministic too. It seems to describe a perfect, harmonic view of the world which I simply don't buy. Yes, there is such a thing as cause and effect, but to suppose that humans can interpret, or indeed benefit fully or control these causes and effects is silly. The environment affects you and your decisions, but 2 seconds before it does you were not determined to react to it, you react to it in a determined way once it does so, but to suppose that you are somehow affecting that, or that in fact your actions affect the environment itself (in any significant way) - that is improbable.

For example: let's say Your brain operates on a biological level, on a physical level, that "predetermines" you to flee instead of fight in all situations. At some point, an event takes place which prevents you from running so your only option is to fight. You do so, even though you were "predetermined" to flee. Your "fate" has just been altered by the environment.

I'm not necessarily arguing against hard determinism - I'm saying there are different types of determinism, different independent mechanisms of determinism that operate in different people and different sets of environment, which than cross and affect one another, changing each-others' paths. Like a string of linear paths that continue to run, and then collide with one another, and branch out into different directions, only to collide at some point again. It's not "one big machine with lots of small cogs" it's many different machines of various sizes, with their own cogs that smash into one another and create different machines with fewer or lesser different cogs than before. This kind of randomness is what I call freedom. Because in that clashing moment, each cog in each machine has its own predetermined path that is obstructed, and what emerges from that clash is something that was perhaps never intended to begin with, and it operates under the laws of chance and randomness - randomness or chaos is what I like to call freedom.

Dear Crash Course, I think you'd confused fatalism with determinism.

See, fatalism is the idea that all events are fated - in other words despite our best efforts to go against fate, we can't escape it. (Oedipus and everyone involved made specific decisions to prevent the prophecy from coming true, but it still did)

Determinism is the idea that all events are necessary outcomes of events that came before it. That makes it sound similar but it makes it vastly different - see, determinism is the idea that if you change enough factors in Oedipus' story, Oedipus would have gone on a different route and the prophecy would not have come true. Say, you change one simple factor that his (prospective) foster family didn't walk past the same place. Oedipus dies in the wilderness. He doesn't kill his father nor marry his mother.

However, Fatalism would be the idea that no matter how many things you change in the story, Oedipus would still go on to kill his father and marry his mother.

I still don't get it, i mean, why are we assuming that determinism is right? Sure, the chain of events leading up to a choice are unchangeable, since they are in the past, but the actual choice is not necessarily determined by that "unbroken chain of events", and the fact that our choices are determined by belief desire or temperament does not mean that what I will do ten years from now is determined already today. This is basically like saying that randomness is determined, and that's just wrong, because the future is always in motion, and each choice influences the next, but it does not determine it. Taking the coin example: lets say I chose oatmeal for heads and cream of wheat for tails; the most important thing the video ignores here is that while your decision to flip the coin to make a choice for you could be considered pre-determined, as well as the possible choices of breakfast of heads or tails, the OUTCOME of the flip is truly random. So, you made the choice to choose either oatmeal or cream of wheat for either heads or tails, but the coin made the final choice and none of the previous unbroken chain of events had any influence in the outcome of the flip, thus making it truly random. You can say that maybe the air conditions in the room, the weight of the coin, the strength of my flip determine the outcome of the flip even before i do it, but none of those things was influenced by either belief, desire, or temperament, and the chain of events that lead me to being in such circumstances, in that room, with that coin etc, were not influenced by belief desire or temperament (for example whether i put my wallet close to my desk or far from my desk is an event that just as randomly could have been different). That doesn't necessarily support the "free will" view, but at least I believe it is a good argument against determinism. Now, what to call this new idea, I don't know.

You say Hard Determinism is "hard to refute", even as you say they admit that we "can't pinpoint the exact factors that led to an action" but can only "IN THEORY isolate them". In other words, determinists only assume that human behavior can be absolutely predicted because they have faith that their inability to do so presently is ignorance of things that can, at least in theory, be learned.

In the same way that Free Will Libertarians can't explain the science of how Agent Causation breaks from Physical Causation, but still choose to believe in such a break for the interim, Determinists choose to believe such a break doesn't exist, and that any experience or action appearing to contradict this (human behavior that appears to act against best available predictions) is only because of some unknown factor that, they assure us, is present.

So the real question isn't, where does the evidence point -- because both theories require faith that something unknown still exists -- but what you choose to believe. Except, if you're a determinist, then you see said choice as already being determined; and if you're a Libertarian, then choosing to believe you don't have a choice is an act of Bad Faith.

So one thing this didn't mention is complicating evidence that calls hard determinism into question. While the fact that every effect had a cause has yet to be refuted, the qualia he talked about in a previous episode stands outside this. The fact that pleasure feels good and pain feels bad and the way red looks red - these are all things that aren't explained by reductionism. Imagine: how do you know that the color you think of as red is what other people see when they see red? You can't know. They might see green when you see red, and they have all the same associations with green that you do with red. In fact, the fact that wee observe through our body at all is something unexplainable by reductionism. We hear, see, smell, and taste simultaneously. Simultaneity is impossible for a given point in space, and so you can't explain our observance by reducing them to their smallest part.

Even if you only have the sense of sight (nothing else), your eye is still seeing a huge number of points of light simultaneously. You could imagine that we're seeing only one point of light at any given time, but are seeing each one so quickly that they create a full image - but even then you have to concede the simultaneity of remembering all the other points of light you've recently seen. There's no way out of it.

The Oedipus scenario doesn't apply to determinism. This is because, although Oedipus was influenced by his surroundings when he made the choice to run away, determinism (unlike fatalism) acknowledges the empirically undeniable fact that our behaviour does affect our environment. Oedipus' choice to run away was triggered by an event and he did not have free will when he made the decision but his making of the decision would, rationally, effect later events. The idea that he would follow the prophecy no matter what it is fatalistic and not rational and deterministic.

I believe that you have made an error, and it is no simple error because the line is so fine that many people make the error in stating it. In this video you stated that Oedipus was fated to Kill his Father and Marry his mother, and then you went to list the causal chain p⊃q, q⊃r, r⊃s... ∴ p⊃s, however, the key word which is the Fatal flaw is the inclusion of the term Fated. Many people mistake Hard-Determinism for Fatalism and much of this video has made this error.

The best example I can think of is when you literally threw personal responsibility at one point during the monologue about Hard-Determinism. Let us use Oedipus as an example in name. For example, if Oedipus had been taught his entire life that killing was bad yet still ended up someone, then, in respects to the social contract, i.e., the governmental bodies which have agree on the laws that the people of the land have agreed on, e.g., killing is wrong, then knowing this rule he killed a man, then yes, he has a personal responsibility in regards to the social contract, and he should be prosecuted for the murder; however, if we remove the social contract, then we have a much more difficult time understanding personal responsibility at all, even in the libertarian sense of the word. If we were to agree that the first responsibility a person has to themselves is to keep themselves alive, are they morally bad, or irresponsible when they die? What if the only way to survive was to steal? In this sense, I am making a callback to Aristotle's Mixed Actions in his argument, which in itself is neither of the presented opinions because it relies on alternate possibilities, I have the options to steal and live longer, or not and die. Being a Determinist, I would steal food to live longer, and if I was a Libertarian, I believe the choice to eat sounds more reasonable that to let myself starve to death. This would satisfy his mixed actions, which is why this is the third view compatibilist. I disagree with Aristotle, and I believe the system to be Deterministic, yet, I believe the Determinist would claim that, at the most base level, they have a personal responsibility to keep themselves alive. This example shows that even without the social contract, a person has some sort of responsibility, unless you like Nietzsche and would just give into Nihilism - although Absurdism is fun to, Looking at you Camus. Now Fatalism would say that you are fated to steal and leave it at that; however, Fatalism does not care about the causal chain in the actions. This is the problem with your video Fatalism leaves no room for personal responsibility where, I hope, I gave a Valid, which I check some rules, and can show you that Determinism does not remove personal responsibility.

I just have one problem with hard determinism. If all events are caused by past events, then what was the cause of the very first event? I understand that this is the question of why did the big bang occur, which has proposed answers including that the question itself is fundamentally asking "what happened before things started happening" but also a number of alternate approaches.

One of the previous videos taught us St. Thomas Aquinas' proofs of God. One of these was the argument from motion, where everything that is set in motion must have been set in motion by something else. This cannot extend ad infinitum and thus there was the need for an unmoved mover, God, to set things in motion. The counterargument to this was that the argument was self defeating: why was God exempt from the rule of everything needing to be set in motion from something else, and nothing else was?

I ask the same about hard determinism proposing that all of our choices are a result of the past events. Why must we be subjected to past events, when there was a first event that could not have been caused by any other? If this reasoning is correct, then would we too have to accept Aquinas' proof was correct?

As I remember being mentioned earlier in the series, it is possible to accept a conclusion but refute the argument that was used to draw the conclusion. I believe that environment plays an overwhelming role in all decision making, though I would not consider the argument valid enough to claim beyond reasonable doubt that it is true just yet.

On a more lifestyle note, I don't like the idea of not believing I have free will. Until it is proven we don't, I'll live with the assumption I do and use it to take full responsibility for my actions and make decisions regarding how to make myself a better person every day. Philosophy should be used as a tool to hone your thinking for use in life: I fail to see how believing hard determinism will improve people. (Other than the fact that it is a very strong argument upon which maybe one day believers of free will will use to improve their own)

In my personal opinion, the arguments of what it means to be "free" and what it means for things to be "determined" aren't really as set in stone as they're made out to be. Sure, yes, everyone is predisposed toward certain actions, we don't have the ability to freely turn our life around unless it's caused by something, but consider this; Why does something that is caused by something else, have to be determined? The combination of different factors alone should guarantee that things could not have been determined, but are in fact caused by a multitude of occurrences that happened to happen at the same time. Blindly saying things are determined just because you can logically backtrace them to a cause does not proof that they are, in fact, determined. All it does is abuse the nature of time as we know it to pretend to proof a concept that's been constructed by us.

Let me put it in a simpler light; Say you're tossing a coin and it lands on Heads. Some guy now says "Hah, I knew it was going to land on Heads." Hard Determinism is that guy. It's easy to point out the outcome of a certain event after it's transpired. Just because Hard Determinism is hard to refute does not make it the truth. You can imply we're all in a simulated universe right now, with it's own simulated rules, and that's also pretty hard to refute logically. That doesn't mean it's true.

There are a lot of people in the comments claiming that if Hard Determinism were true, than the justice system would crumble and society would plunge into chaos. There are two issues with this line of argument. One: it assumes that the justice system only exists for retribution or vengeance, and Two: how well Determinism aligns with your idea of justice has no bearing on whether it is actually true.

Consider that "He didn't know it was wrong," and "He knew it was wrong, but he did it anyway," still indicates two different brain states. The person who commits a crime with the knowledge that it will harm others is more dangerous, guilty, and in need of punishment/rehabilitation regardless of his autonomy.

Point two is a familiar defense of religion. The story goes that, without the fear of god, people would not act justly, and society would crumble. Notice that it doesn't prove or disprove god's existence. Instead, it just admits of a very pessimistic view of human decency. Is consciousness the brain controlling itself, or just noticing itself? Either way, the truth isn't dictated by the justice system's efficacy.

I can refute determinism with a contradiction-based argument: predicting the future.

1. Everything is determined. (assumption for proof by contradiction.)
2. It is possible to predict future events (from 1, as there is only one possibility)
3. Parts of the universe can react to other parts of the universe. (I know this, because I am thinking about (and thus reacting to) the universe right now.)
4. Some of these reactions can be based on the predictions of future events (from 2 and 3)
5. Some of these prediction-based reactions may be to prevent a "bad" future. (from 4)
6. Those reactions can cause the future prediction to be false.
7. 6 contradicts 2, which in turn means my reasoning is false. Thus, the only premise, determinism, must be false as well.

So, if determinism is false, what isn't determined?...

Ehhh... not quite. I understand the need to simplify (which is why I don't expect this video to delve into the conceptual differences between fatalism, determinism, causation and lawful behavior) but the definitions given for libertarian free will and hard determinism are just wrong.

Both libertarianism and hard determinism are necessarily incompatiblist positions, but neither definition we're given in the video reflects that. The phrase "the belief that some human actions are freely chosen" could equally apply to the compatiblist or incompatibilist notion of free will. And "the belief that all events are caused by past events such that nothing other than what does occur could occur" is merely the definition of determinism simpliciter and could equally apply to soft determinism or hard.

The next video icon at the end says there will soon be a video about compatibilism, but that might come off rather strange when the incompatibilist assumptions of what we've just covered have been confused or omitted from the definitions.
