Am I crazy to think that: quantum uncertainty + hard determinism = probabilistic determinism?

Reality seems to be on a strange continuum where anything in the past is deterministic and the future is probabilistic.

All past events should be measurable prove with question that the world operates under hard determinism, up until and just before we hit the "present moment."

Quantum mechanics says everything in the future is some kind of probability. With an infinite amount of time there is an infinite amount of quantum flux and makes the universe 100% unknown/uncertain at this imaginary time in the future. As a time in the future gets closer to the present, uncertainly goes down, as the amount of quantum effects still yet to occur also decreases.

So a millionth or a billionth of second in future the probability for the world following the determine thread is something like 99.99999...% (or so) with an extremely low chance to deviate.

What is disconcerting is the time of present that melds past and future. The past has certainty = 100% because all events are done and unchanging. The future is 0% certainty at infinity time treading to 100% certainty as time trends to present due to quantum uncertainty. These are two equations that meet and create a discontinuous graph with an inflection point at time present.

This leaves me able to explain the past and future but unable to explain the present. A present where we are continuously in some kind of transition between a past that is complete deterministic and a future that always has some level of quantum uncertainty/probability. Not being able to explain this transition occurring in the present leaves me unable to make a complete theory that defines the clock work of the universe and is unsatisfying.

The libertarian view is only a problem if you assume people are made of something more than atoms. If you believe we're made of atoms like other material objects, and you admit these two things:

1. Everything happens (everything possible according to the limitations of physical laws) and...

2. Information is made locally inaccessible to us when we perceive an event with different potential outcomes.

...then there's no problem. We split, along with everything else. We live in a deterministic multiverse (high level and basic building blocks). But we can choose to be a specific "version" of ourselves within our own universe. There are many versions of everything, including us. Here's a good start to learning the math: http://ucispace.lib.uci.edu/discover?fq=author_filter:everett,\+hugh\|\|\|Everett,\+Hugh

The real problem we have today with free will is the trampling of individual liberty by other people within our own universe. Individual choice must be maximized and protected. Every kind of collectivist thinking must be viewed with caution. There is no authoritative justification for new sources of knowledge. We're made of the same stuff as the chair we're sitting upon, but people can create knowledge by uncovering information. This is the reason we're special, and what gives us a subjective perception of free will (even if it is partly an illusion).

Individual creativity is the only generator of new knowledge. This creativity is maximized by promoting the freedom of individual liberty. Maintaining and increasing the connections among individuals is important, but recognizing individual differences is fundamental. Error correction through criticism is vital, but groupthink is dangerous. It's a tricky balance. I'm seeing an ever-increasing number of terribly perverted connotations of the word "diversity," always by politicians and human resources departments.

Government must be limited. Individualism must be encouraged and protected. Justificationism must be condemned. Intellectuals are dangerous if they don't understand the importance of individual liberty (some are more dangerous than others, like bureaucrats/"social science" experts/astrologers/homeopaths/etc).

Scientific experts support experimentation and proof, but they are not always the sources of genuinely new theories. They don't prove anything. Statistics and probabilities alone don't prove anything. Only logical explanations which are hard-to-vary (David Deutsch) can serve as legitimate proof for a theory. Hugh Everett III defined how theories must explain both what we observe AND what we are not equipped to observe (but we know occurs). By growing knowledge we now know that we're spinning around the sun, for example, and not vice-versa.

Individual liberty = Creativity = The Growth of Knowledge.

I think this combination of Belief + Desire + Temperament could in fact, by itself, be defined as the exercising of our freedom. When we think about freedom, what do we attribute it as? The ability to do what we want, when we want, within the confines of possibility and/or reason? If so, what more is there to it but the application of our beliefs, desires and temperaments? If we are granted that our beliefs, desires and temperaments can be enacted within the bounds of possibility and reason, how much more "freedom" do we really need than that?

When we think of "freedom" in most cases, it's these external factors - the possibilities restricted by the world around us and the reason by which we govern ourselves - that we really think of when we consider our freedom to be restricted. But apart from these things, I have no problem breaking down my observed personal freedom to make choices as the simple application of belief, desire and temperament. Apart from our thoughts, what else are we, if not defined by our beliefs, desires and temperaments? What are we without these things? What freedom would there even be without these things? We may be capable of making choices, but we would have no compulsion to do so.

This may have no bearing on the argument, as far as libertarianism or determinism is concerned, but I for one have no problem accepting this position, because when my actions are determined, I am ultimately both the determined and the determinator. And many more of the determinators have also been determined by a combination of my own previously determined actions as well as other outside factors, all of which have gone into shaping my beliefs, desires, and temperaments. If you track this trail of determination back to our own origins, you ultimately get to what most Oscar-speeches have been telling us for years - that the ultimate determinators for our actions are our own parents, whose actions caused the chain of events that resulted in your existence, as well as the existence of your mind, and the inception of your beliefs, desires and temperament, such as they are.

Ultimately, we are the ones who determine what we do, even if we are not entirely aware of what we are doing. You can look at it as not being in control of your fate, but I argue that whatever combination of determining factors come into play, no matter how far back they go, that the individual still has a hand in almost all of them.

I don't think hard determinism creates big implications with responsibility. In this deterministic world, you'd be compelled to seek out the humans that made certain wrong choices, which resulted in the bad events you will be punishing for. Then you'd want to 'punish' those humans, by which you mean to give them an experience that will affect their future actions in such a way that those humans will not make the same mistake if given another chance. We'd call those humans that needed the punishment the 'responsible' ones.

Also, what determines a person's initial approach towards their first experiences in life? And then their response? We all come to exist at some point and we haven't existed before that, so there must be a first experience of something for each of us. We get to respond to one event without having been influenced by the outside world before that. Scientifically, you'd say that initial approach is determined by your genetic code, which does result from the mechanism of the physical world and spiritually you might say that is determined by your soul. Either way, you can now pinpoint your personality. If holding the genetic code view, then yes, you are a part of the physical world, your very existence is determined by the physical world, and your choice could never be more free than what you made at your first moment of existence. If holding the spiritual view, then you've had something like a free choice, and you've determined the rest of your life, in a way, at that one point in time.

I haven't studied philosophy, but there are a few things said here that I take issue with. Everyone seems to agree that cause and effect is an infallible thing, and that's what hard determinism relies on, but it seems to me that there are a lot of cases where figuring out what caused what is far too complicated to do, especially where human minds are involved, so no one can determine what the chain of events was or predict future events with 100% accuracy. You'd have to have perfect knowledge. Therefore, there is no "fate" for you to be confident in or to avoid like the plague because there's no way of knowing what the future holds exactly. The concept only exists in fiction. Everyone is making choices with limited information about both the actual circumstances surrounding the choices and their eventual results, so we all have free will in so far as we're guessing and taking stabs in the dark without anyone or anything guiding our actions. Assuming of course there isn't a person manipulating your actions, but we all do that to each other to an extent, and the manipulator can't control your actions perfectly without perfect knowledge. Also, you say that brain states determine mental states, therefore making them physical and subject to physical laws. While I agree to the extent that there's no soul or anything separate from the body that's making decisions, you can only say that there's correlation, not causation. The subjective experience of our mental faculties is inaccessible, at least presently.

Ash'ari doctrine states that actions of contingencies are created by God. However, it is not determinism per se. It is like this: human beings have something called "kasb", which means that we earn our actions. I.e. God wills and creates our actions based on our own wills.

So let's say you want to pick up a sword. You will to pick this up, since we have something called "kasb" (mentioned earlier), God wills and creates the action of you picking up the sword based on your own desire. Had God not willed for you to pick up the sword, you would not be able to, which is possible. Another example: when you launch a brick into a glass, the glass breaks because God created the action for the glass to break, not because the brick and glass have inherent qualities. However, God often is consistent in these matters, hence you can predict it. When something happens which we are not used to i.e. imagine the glass would not break, we deem this a miracle, but this is simply God not willing and creating the action of the glass breaking.

This is how Ash'aris explain good and evil in the world in spite of there being a God: we earn our actions thus they are created based on our will. However, these actions shall be judged after death and on the Day of Judgement. If one does not believe in the Day of Judgement it would lead to good and evil being equal since noone would have to account for it. Then again, Ash'aris also believe that good and evil is only known through Divine revelation.

There are two angles of attack that one could take in order to object hard determinism in my opinion:
1- What we call "Free Will" isn't the ability to be completely full of options, but rather that the chain of causes and parameters governing our actions are so complex, and the interactions between different agents with a complex chain of causation, are so subject to entropy... That it actually matches our definition of free will, which is basically a chain of causation that is too complex to fully observe.

If, say, the most optimized computer made with all the atoms and all the energy of the universe couldn't predict perfectly, at the atomic level, what is about to happen, despite knowing 100% of the parameters of an action... Then that action, despite being ruled by hard determinism, being impossible to determine, amounts to free will. Take a big enough action, or a big enough precision level, and that impossible to determine result can be obtained.

Or alternatively, if a chain of causation is too complex for a human brain to physically process, then it is "complex enough" to be called free will.

 2- At a quantum level, there is some degree of probability rather than determinism. Since this degree of probability has an influence over what we consider the physical world, then our biological states are in fact impossible to fully attribute to determinism, which in turn means that our mental states cannot be fully attributed to determinism either.

One could argue that everything is also determined at the quantum level, just that measuring it will influence the result... But if there is physically no way to observe an action without influencing its result, it means that determinism is actually UNABLE to predict anything, because the very act of prediction will necessarily change the result, which invalidates the act of prediction and is a paradox. And so, if nothing can be fully determined, then nothing is deterministic in the first place.

In that case, what we call "hard determinism" wouldn't be as absolute, just like in my first point when I say that what we call "free will"' may not need to be as absolute. Hard determinism might just amount to the ability to narrow outcomes to a small enough range of possibilities that it "seems" to be a unique possibility for our human brains, at best.

I find it a little silly that people think there is such strong evidence for determinism. All we have evidence for is that abstract objects and certain aspects of biological processes are deterministic. The mind is clearly very different in its properties (whether emergent or not) than everything else. The very existence of consciousness opens up this question. Until we understand the human brain far better, determinism is no better than faith. I've not seen any logically valid deductive argument for determinism. Those that exist are defeatable. The very fact that we feel so strongly that we're free should be more than enough reason to reserve judgment until further evidence presents itself.

Add to that a huge swathe of problematic consequences of this view (I've seen counters to these in the comments below, but find them logically inconsistent), and it seems to me that the default is no position at this time. A lot of the support of determinism seems to come as much from assumption and faith as any religious belief (at least for the moment), and is spoken with the same certainty. It should therefore be regarded with the same skepticism.

If you can't refute hard determinism (and I don't think you really can), then in this case you couldn't held anyone responsible for his actions. Could you punish a murderer? If he was determined to kill someone and he couldn't do other, can he be guilty?

It's important to distinguish between determinism (a sensible philosophical position) and fate (what happened to Oedipus). Fate allows you to 'struggle' but all of your attempts to escape that fate are futile. Determinism just says that every action you take is the only option you could've taken under those exact conditions. If you were fated to get a certain job, then you could talk nonsense during the interview, or just not attend at all, and still get the job. But if you will get the job, according to determinism, all that happens is that the chain of causality will result in you taking the right course of action, do the right things to impress your interviewers and get the job; and you will feel like you're actively making these decisions, but that feeling too was caused by previous events (all the way down to the sodium and potassium ions in your neurons).

This argument always assumes two extremes that cannot exist. You can never be free from influence, but likewise you also shape those influences. Ultimately, the choice vs. influence is so interwoven that the distinction becomes outright impossible to make. Hard determinism assumes that because something happens that is line with an experience or influence, that the experience or influence is the sole cause. Quantum uncertainty, at least certain theories pertaining to it, offer factual basis for refuting determinism. And really, the almost dualistic appearance of much of the natural world isn't much different. They two sides aren't separate, they exist with and because of the other. Like and dark, life and death, cause and effect. Why would consciousness be any different? The reason it cannot be easily refuted or proven is the same reason we cannot tell if anything but our own thoughts actually exist. We have no actual, first hand insight. The thoughts of others, the effects of choice would require testing with controls that cannot exist. A control free from all influence, which would simply be nonexistence. Ultimately, we are shaped by everything around us, but likewise, we shape them. Our thoughts are fueled by chemicals, but our thoughts, if we decide to alter them, can alter the chemistry. I also wonder as to why thinking would would even exist in a deterministic world, why sentience would even happen over mindless instinctive non-thought. I haven't seen an argument that has made the reconciliation of a limited choice system ( limited certain factors, notions, identities, constraints of possibility) with the deterministic. Why should we expect choices to be free from influence? Likewise why should we discount choice, Schrodinger's cat, or experiential factors? Emotion and rationality are tempered against one another. Instinct is tempered against consciousness. We simply because we don't understand reality or consciousness well enough for a sensible answer.

Except the Universe is not deterministic. Einstein believed that, but QM fundamentally forbids the Universe to be deterministic. Because of the probabilistic nature, one can never completely deduce what made mind go from one state to another. Quantum Probability and Particle/wave Duality functioning on even macro-molecules dictates that the universe is not entirely deterministic. A deterministic universe is a universe in which every event in the FUTURE is pre-determined, and can only happen in one particular way, and there is zero possibility for divergence. However every single quantum event, every nuclear decay, every photon, every free electron, adds a tiny little variable that's based on probability, not deterministic law, and can have a cascading effect on events. For instance I perform the double-slit experiment, one photon at a time, the location the photon lands looks deterministic, but the double slit experiment has actually proven that this is not the case, the photon is in fact functioning as a wave, and therefor its final position is a random distribution on an interference pattern. the pattern is deterministic, but the location and distribution within the pattern, is based on probability and randomness, not any deterministic cause. If I then translate that photon's landing point into a value that is used for a decision, then there would be branching out futures, based on the different probable locations that particular photon could have landed, and therefor the result of the experiment is non-deterministic. That said, radioactive decay functions on these same lines, and our BRAINS contain radioactive elements, such as Potassium, and Iodine, reactions with which will be influenced by whether or not that atom or molecule has decayed or not, and therefor the processes of our very thoughts, are influenced by default by the same probability.

This means that on one hand, the universe is not deterministic, but on the other hand, we are not in true control of our thoughts, but neither is a purely deterministic system, instead, a random number generator is. We're about as free as a simulation.

Additionally, that aside, if we're not free to make our own choices, how can we morally or ethically hold a person accountable for their individual actions, good or bad? criminals are nolonger responsible for their own actions, it was deterministic, you can't punish what they had no choice in, and scientists and police also have no choice, so you cannot reward them for their accomplishments either. This is why determinism is beaten by freewill / libertarian thought, because the alternative fails to punish the guilty, and refuses to reward the deserving, and is fundamentally unfair, and leads to the collapse of society and social order. beyond that deterministic thought further denies Cartesian skepticism, determinism IS the evil genius .

Wait hold up - hard determinism doesn't contradict personal responsibility, just constrains the possible definitions. (As if it was well-defined in the first place...)

All you have to do is get a sense of what "person" means and what such an entity is "responsible" for. If hard determinism states that my mental processes are predetermined, well we're still talking about a system so complex as to be self-aware and capable of abstraction. That system can see the chain of causality in motion, and its own role in that chain, and therefore can circumscribe its participation as being "it's responsibility."

It's easy to sound right if you just chalk your argument up to, "You don't have free will because somewhere in your brain is the inevitable cause of every decision you make. We can't find or explain it, but we know it's there." The fact that I can choose to do something completely uncharacteristic or undesirable or even harmful to myself is proof that there is free will. I can choose to drop everything tomorrow, drop out of school, and become a monk. I wouldn't like it, I'd lose all my friends, and I am not religious, but I could do it. The existence of making decisions based on a whim proves that we aren't pre-wired to only make decisions that are a combination of our beliefs, desires, and temperaments.

I can't help but turn to quantum mechanics in this case, because subatomic particles and the principles governing those subatomic particles ultimately "determine" the natural world. Correct me if I'm wrong, but haven't we proven that quantum mechanics is inherently probablistic? Of course, it could be the case that we have yet to find a more accurate mechanism to describe quantum mechanics, but I can't help but think that we've reached the frontier of physical causal chain. And if we're looking for something physical (particle, force, or otherwise) that caused something, then we will inevitably run into the problem of an infinite regression.

To elaborate on what I mean, imagine the baseball example Hank gave. The ball is hit because of neurons in the brain which were destined to fire in a particular way, those neurons firing were caused by the 4 fundamental forces (one way or another), those forces were caused by previous forces ever since the beginning of the universe itself, then what caused the universe to exist and thereby determine everything? I realize that we may not have the capacity to know what came before the universe, but it's still an important stance to consider for hard determinism. Was the universe caused by something else or did it spawn from absolute nothingness (thereby not being determined by anything)? Did it cause itself to exist? What if time has no beginning nor end, and we truly are free because everything that could be determined already has been determined?

As of now I'm still a supporter of determinism, but I think that free will has some support that many people often dismiss because determinism is really simple to grasp and seemingly without internal fallacies.

The arguments against the homunculus free will is surely dead and there is not separate non-physical part of us that's directing our choices. But, at the same time, the argument about determinism requires that we be looking at the system of a person from /the outside/ perspective. This is fine if you're doing science and need a non-subjective perspective; but this is philosophy and we don't need to stick to those rules here. From the subjective perspective we are physical beings with stored data in our heads. It is ours, we own it. Just like we own the bodies we control. Actually more than own, we incorporate it, we are it.

So when the data in our heads "makes" us choose a thing, that data is /us/ making that choice. Even if the data is mixed with data from our senses that morning. The only way we wouldn't have free will is if the data that causes the choice never becomes incorporated into the self and the choice is thus forced upon us. Information is truly a thing of self and non-self. Information you are, and information you are not. This is fundamentally different from inanimate objects like balls rolling down hills, because they don't have any information about their trajectory, it only becomes information when we measure it and incorporate it. That's why we can predict where a ball will go and the ball can not.

I think a lot of the problems with this particular subject is the definition of will, free, self and determined. We want to imagine freedom to mean capable of seperating ourselves from the universe, so we're disappointed when we find ourselves inseparable from it. But just because we're a mutable constituent of the deterministic universe doesn't mean that we aren't owners of that piece of the universe determining it's path, just that we're always going to have to understand things around us in order to understand ourselves and why we make the choices we do. Introspection is one of the most powerful executions of data and I hope we learn to understand it too.

You can most definitely hold both those ideas as true, because everything is alternating deterministic and non deterministic depending on how large a scale you look on.

Quantum: Non deterministic,

Atomic--Cellular: deterministic,

Animals and people: non deterministic, even though they are made up of deterministic cells. (a more accurate term would be probabilistic)

Planetary things like weather and plate tectonics, all the way up to galactic movement: Deterministic.

And, at the very largest scale, if you believe the universe was created from nothingness at random with random rules and random properties expanding for no real reason in an unexplainable way; Non deterministic.

A lot of philosophers seem to like forgetting that we, and our brains, and all processes within them are physical, just like the rest of the universe. The mind is a physical thing just as much as the game running on your computer is a physical thing. Both consist of charges and chemicals carrying out processes. I'd like to argue that one can be free of will but "fated" to do one particular thing no matter what, simply because previous experience has caused you to decide to do a particular thing and also because we are not obliged to follow the commands of other entities (we aren't automatons). Using Hank's oatmeal example, we can all agree that Hank freely chose to have oatmeal that day. There's likely reasons for it. Maybe he had it before and enjoyed it. Maybe he's never had it and wanted to try. Maybe he didn't like it and wanted to give it another chance, or he could have had one of those "Lol, I'm so random" moments and his mind landed on oatmeal. No matter the reason, this was the only thing that could have happened at that exact moment, however, it was not really "fate," as fate only works if you think about events backwards, pretending that there is a destination that events are leading to and not accepting that time works in only one direction and is created second by second.
And then there's quantum physics, where even particle behavior doesn't seem to be determined.  Maybe our choices are traced down to true randomness at the subatomic level.

It is easy to appeal to cause and effect, one thing to another, and to time. But isn't that an illusion itself? Isn't it a human feature to distinguish? What if there is simply an ever-present, our brain structure moving within it, formulating memories that give us an illusion that a past is something that is accessible? What if the movement we experience is simply a fluid, non-digital phenomena that con only be reduced to cause and effect through our intuition? Would determinism still be sound? Can something be determined if it, and its causes are not really separated that way?

I think of the "things just are" argument to fight against the worldview we impose upon the real world. The universe is indifferent to our preferences.

Also, this subject always brings me back to Morpheus' saying: "Remember Neo, what happened, happened. And could not have happened any other way." Seriously, The Matrix can be used for an entire philosophy course.

Hard Determinism is a bit of an odd position to hold when quantum physics states that "things" exist primarily as probability states until they interact with each other. This works especially well given that neurons are very close to the quantum world, given they're small molecular structures, operating via even smaller processes. Returning to the macro scale, while its very easy for the brain to pick up environmental influences, it can hold onto them, and when it chooses to act on them is unpredictable; to the point that actions that could result from those influences can only be described as "probable" outcomes, and even then its hard to determine when or in what circumstances those actions will happen, especially given many of those influences create contradicting possible outcomes while existing simultaneously inside the same brain.

I'm absolutely a hard determinist, but getting rid of personal responsibility as a useful concept throws the baby out with the bathwater.  Even if everything we do and think has a deterministic cause, it's impossible (or impracticable, at the very least) to know all those causes, so we may as well have free will for all practical purposes.  It's an illusion, but it's a beneficial one.

Hard determinism, while interesting to think about, is not good science because it is not falsifiable--it cannot be tested.  There is no way to go back and test if an alternate "choice" could have possibly been made.  Until one can devise a way to "test" hard determinism, it is about as provable as "God did it".

Hard determinism still struggles to explain what are known as "coin-on-edge" decisions- choices made by humans in which there are truly no perceptible distinctions or preference for an option, aka a dilemma. Normally this should result in confusion or indesicsion in a truly deterministic world, yet humans will still be able to choose without conscious or unconscious thought. For example, suppose I'm putting ketchup on a hamburger- do I put the ketchup above the patty, or below it? It won't affect the deliciousness of the burger either way and if it's not a cheeseburger then both sides of the patty are equally accessible- so, deterministically, this should be an intense mental process in order to find some way of preferring one side over the other- but, really, who puts careful thought into which side they put their ketchup on? Thus humans ARE clearly capable of making otherwise impossible decisions without any real thought (a feature which can also get us into trouble with cognitive dissonance).

I have always reconciled this conflict by avoiding absolutes- they lead to mutually exclusive results. We don't have total free will (all options), but we also don't have totally determined fates (no options), either. It seems to me that determinism covers the options from which we may choose, and free will covers our choice. Using the oatmeal for breakfast example:
Total determinism (no option): You could only have eaten oatmeal.
Total free will (all options): You could eat anything.
My middle ground: You could eat anything that won't poison/harm you, and to which you have access and that you can afford. You may not be able to afford a grass-fed steak covered in edible gold flakes flown in this morning from Japan, you don't have access to my dead grandmother's famous pancakes, and eating plutonium will kill you, so you can't really say that you could've eaten anything for breakfast this morning; however, you likely also had cereal at home, possibly some breakfast meats in the fridge, and you could easily buy a breakfast sandwich on the way to work, so you had available options that you did not choose.
I first came upon this issue when I was younger, and people would tell me "you can be anything when you grow up." At first, when I was very young, I took this quite literally- superhero was in the cards for me. As I grew up, obviously I realized that they meant I would have many options, but that I would still be limited in those choices. I am a white male- I could not be black or a woman (barring surgery that I would personally avoid). I will never have superpowers. Though I can change many things about myself, and have many options in terms of employment and lifestyle, I am nonetheless limited in those options (free will interacting with determinism).
You really run into this problem though with theology. If god is omniscient, and knows everything that will ever happen, then it cannot be said that he gave us free will, because we will always be acting in accordance with his plan. If we do have free will, then it is impossible to say that god knows what we will do before we make the decision. However, if you are an atheist/nihilist like me, it really doesn't matter, and you don't need to deal in absolutes. Assume that there is no god, no plan, and the universe is indifferent towards us, but there is cause and effect in the physical world- we have certain options available to us (free will), but those options are finite (determinism). They don't have to be mutually exclusive, depending upon how you define/convey the concept; they can coexist and interact upon one another. Choices you make now using free will will determine your available choices in the future.

Okay. I don't buy that the universe is entirely deterministic. Not because of any physical feeling of freedom, but rather by hard science. Quantum physics, though really complicated, is all about probability. Now whichever interpretation you ascribe to whether hidden variables or everett's many worlds, there is no denying that all particles, protons, neutrons, electrons, and other less common ones obey quantum laws and therefore exist as probability wobbles. While cells are incredibly larger than atoms and subject to less probability fluctuations, they too have probability determined by the atoms, namely brownian motion and ETC (electron-transport chain) reactions. Larger still is an organism, subject to even less probability fluctuations, but still based at some level on the probability of the lowest level. So you see our actions are not perfectly pre-determined, but let us not jump to the conclusion that we are free. This just means that our actions cannot be 100% determined. Embracing freedom would mean that we have control over the random fluctuations of the atoms in our body which is preposterous. So I guess my term would be general determinism instead of hard determinism, and would go something like this: Since certain aspects of the universe are random, those aspects echo up through the chains of causality eventually generating a somewhat random outcome. Therefore not all actions are pre-destined.

Whenever I've spoken to a libertarian on free will, I've always run them around the same circle with this simple question and NEVER gotten a straightforward answer: what determines the choices of agents?  All agents' choices are determined by a previous mental state, temperament, or desire, but those aren't chosen by the agent freely at all.  If this were true, that would lead to an infinite regress of choosing desires/mental states/etc. in order to explain how the action based off of any one particular previous state is made.  So we have to accept that agents' choices are made as a result of previous brain states that the brain has had, which we cannot choose, and which can have occurred very recently or a long time ago.  But since our choice to do what we do every time we do something is the result of the previous brain state we were just in, how can we say we're free?

I personally believe in Soft Determinism. Like Hard Determinism, Soft Determinism believes that everything is determined through cause and events. The only real difference, or at least how my philosophy professor explained it, is that Hard Determinism believes in a master plan of everything. That something will happen no matter what, for example Oedipus fulfilling the prophecy of killing his dad and marrying his mom. Soft determinism believes that there is no master plan. Things happen just because that is where cause and effect brought it. I do not believe in faith or destiny. Everything that has happened, only happened because of what happened before it.

Theism gives something of an escape clause from determinism. The physical world, rather than being deterministic, is simply consistent - it operates in line with the consistent (i.e. unchanging) free will of its God. The reductionist argument therefore no longer strictly applies - though one could still argue that people aren't free, in that they act in line with that God's sovereign will. I believe that we have no control over our decisions, but also that the future state of the universe is not rigidly determined by its present one. Because the universe obeys the laws of quantum mechanics, which only deal in probabilities instead of rigidly defined outcomes, and because many aspects of the universe's structure have mathematically chaotic features, the small random fluctuations produced at the quantum level quickly mushroom into large and undetermined differences in the future states of the universe. Thus, although we do not decide which path we follow through life, that path is not rigidly determined, and what happened to Oedipus in the story could not happen in the real world.

Causal inevitability is not a meaningful constraint. It is exactly identical to you being you, doing what you do, and choosing what you choose. (Anyone want to try to prove otherwise?)Oh, and, of course, you could have done otherwise. The practical meaning of "I could have done A rather than B" is that, at the time of my deliberation, both A and B were available to me to choose from. The restaurant had steak and lobster dinners on the menu. So, I could have chosen either one. One of them was the causally inevitable choice. But both of them were real possibilities available to me at the time. The fact of inevitability does not cancel the fact that I had two real possibilities to choose from. And, as it happens, inevitability will immediately conform to the one I choose. There is no point in disputing that one of the choices was inevitable. However, the only way I could determine which choice was inevitable was to go through a mental process where I estimated which option would best satisfy my needs and desires. As it turns out, the fact of universal causal inevitability is about the most useless fact in the physical universe. And it is this lack of relevance and utility that causes the practical mind to ignore it. It is also a fact that 2 + 2 = 4 and that a clear sky appears blue. However, those facts do me no good in choosing between the steak and the lobster. The fact that my choice will be inevitable is also useless. Now if you could tell me in advance what my choice would be, then that would be useful. But you can't. I still have to make the choice myself, for my own purpose and to satisfy my own reasons. And that is all that free will is: a person deciding for themselves what they WILL do. The "free" part has nothing to do with freedom from causal inevitability. The "free" part refers to "freedom from coercion or other undue influence". If you hold a gun to my head and force me to order steak, when I'd really rather have lobster, then you have subjugated my will to yours, and my will is no longer free.

+CrashCourse you should add scientific evidence for and against each ideology. back in the Era before quantum theory (classical theory) it seemed obvious the world was deterministic since the objects of this world followed dynamic rules.

after quantum theory, it was puzzling that the world was either deterministic or not because the state a particle was measured was undeterministic. determinists in the field believe there could exist hidden variables unaccounted for that can determine the state. so far this does not seem to be true since Bell's theorem proves these hidden variables can't be local and Leggett proved a subset of nonlocal hidden variable theories can't be true either. this does not disprove nonlocal determinism as a whole but it makes it less probable.

I think that the idea of responsibility still applies, but it's a much more difficult concept to deal with because it deals more-so with human rewiring and hypothetical additional options instead of the libertarian idea of additional options.

You want to teach people to behave in a certain way, and include punishments for breaking those rules, because we know that those act as deterrents that can prevent bad behavior and get a happier and more well-functioning society. Remember how, in the video, Hank talked about different factors at play that influence your decision making? If we didn't have any kind of beliefs about what's right and wrong, we would be more likely to do bad things. So we want to teach these things to people so that they make good choices, and then we have punishments in place to help keep in check people's desires that may work against their beliefs, such as the case with stealing that really nice Crash Course "I drink, therefore I am" mug from Hank's desk. Sure, you might know that stealing is wrong, but on the other hand, that's a really nice mug.

So regardless of whether or not someone's wrong actions were deterministic, the fact is that teaching people what's right and wrong, and adding in deterrents, will change how people behave in a positive way. So you should want those things to be there. Even if someone did a bad thing despite having all of those factors, you've still reduced the number of people who would do something bad. And maybe being in jail can change your attitude as well (it's happened before). Plus, rehabilitation works sometimes as well.

So it's less a matter of having additional options and more a matter of setting up more conditions that will deterministically affect people to behave better (or at least behave better statistically speaking; some individuals are entirely, if not then almost entirely, beyond hope).

There's a lot more to gain from this world view than there is to lose, despite people's fears. The notion that we need to operate under the assumption of the existence of free will is honestly so incorrect that it's laughable. People will say that we need to assume free will to construct policies that hold people responsible, for the betterment of society. But this clearly shows that they've identified that these policies have a positive effect on society. Therefore, that's why these policies are good. Because they help society, not because free will exists. It also shows that, given the non-existence of free will, they were still able to see the utility of these policies. Now, there would be some change to how we make policies, and I think that they're fantastic. The idea of vengeance utterly vanishes. If a person is a murderer, we think of them as evil and deserving of punishment. But if we then discovered that they had a brain tumor that suppressed their ability to recognize right and wrong, we'd feel pity, perhaps even compassion. This is what we should feel for murderers, for they are as controlled by their brain chemistry as the man was by his tumor. There are still of course very good reasons to punish someone (remove dangers from society, deter crime, rehabilitation, etc.), but the idea of punishing, torturing, or killing someone because they deserve it is simply incoherent.

The sentence at ~7:48 is wrong, I think. Things like Godel's incompleteness theorem and the Heisenberg uncertainty principle mean that even if the universe is deterministic, it is not possible to figure it out precisely. Like LITERALLY impossible for any intelligent agent or with any technology. Imagine you had a radioactive atom and a particle detector, and if that atom decays in the next 5 minutes you'll have waffles for breakfast, otherwise you'll have cereal. That's a silly example, but I think its not hard to imagine unknowable but deterministic events happening in your brain chemistry constantly, which may cumulatively influence your decision. In this case, you still have no free will, but if your decisions are both deterministic AND unknowable, what's the difference between that and free will? (Serious question)

The way you defined hard determinism makes it false. Quantum mechanics basically completely contradicts it, and when combined with chaos theory, basically makes it false at all levels including the brain. In addition the examples you gave as proof of determinism were not falsifiable. If you have a choice between option A and option B with neither having a clear advantage, then regardless of which choice you pick you could find something in favor of it. If I pick option B you could say that is because of some pro, and I didn't pick option A because of a con. But if I pick option A, you could also say it is because of some pro, and I didn't pick option B because of a con. If both option A and B have pros and cons (which is common among choices), then regardless of which is picked you can point out its pros and the opposition cons. It is ultimately is not falsifiable and thus is a weak argument.

In addition hard determinism is poor at describing choices that the chooser doesn't care about. If I don't care about a choice, then what reason would I pick one over another, determinism claims that if I look deep enough there is a cause yet it merely assumes there is a cause when it isn't clear there is, and it turns out that if I look close enough there isn't always a direct cause but probabilities and unavoidable uncertainty with quantum mechanics and Heisenberg's uncertainty principle.

I view this subject kind of like a record disk. A record disk has grooves that make the needle of the machine go along that groove most of the time. But there isn't a 100% chance that the needle will stay in that groove.

So similarly, our outside world makes certain actions likely, but rarely is it the only option. And there is a chance that you can choose a path different from what you are predisposed to pick, either if you embrace chaotic randomness (but not choosing off of instinct because instinct is predisposed), or you very carefully ponder at the choice before you.

I attribute this to the inherent randomness of the universe. And because of the unsure nature of the universe, our brains are only predisposed to pick something over another. But what if you have a 50-50 chance of doing one thing or the other, and you stop to think about the choice, or maybe you don't. That choice I feel comes down to free will, even if it's not fully free, or on a figurative flip of a coin. Because nature sure isn't predictable, so the idea that our actions are always 100% certain is suspect to me. Just like how the weather channel will only ever give you percent chances of something happening, there is only a percent chance of you making a certain decision.

What about a mix of both? Determinism states that you ate your oatmeal because you require food to live, but what if you instead ate cereal because that tasted nicer? What if you decide to try a new pancake recipe? It's a chain of free decisions caused by previous events. The past existed, but there is nothing to suggest anything beyond the current moment necessarily. If I invest $3000 in a startup, then the cause of the future could be me becoming either rich or $3000 dollars short, but you can't say how specifically my investment will determine either of those events exclusively in a closed environment, when there are two logical outcomes. Based on a series of choices made by the start up, since they choose to divert resources to try and maximise capital (i.e. experimenting without knowing the outcome) then who's to say which event caused the profitability or loss of the company? Clearly some causes end and have no effect whereas others do? In such a case, we are slaves to chaos. There is nothing to suggest that you waking up in the morning will be the same you as before or that you won't die from a suprise nuclear attack, so your choices are necessarily free. 'Surviving the odds' is when you evade the effects or causes where others didn't, and that is determined either by hard chaos or by decisions.

The cause of the subjective perception of free will is ignorance (of causal processes). Once such is known, it becomes understood and even predictable.

For me the act of making an informed choice is the process of weighing my options against my motives to decide the best outcome. I cannot think of a real-world scenario (Please correct me), where my options and motives are not shaped (and therefore determined) by the world around me. Thus by this definition I cannot make a truly free choice. The argument can be made that an uninformed choice is free, but I would argue that an uninformed choice is not a choice at all, merely chance.

Having said that I still feel as though I have agency. Instead of a choice lets consider a puzzle. I don't know the answer to the puzzle and I must find it based upon the rules of the puzzle, which are set by my motives and my options. You may see a certain circularity here, my definition of a puzzle matches my definition of a choice. So in fact it doesn't matter to me if the answer is pre-determined, I experience the same thought process either way.

So I argue that determinism is not incompatible with choice, because choice is a psychological phenomenon, a consequence of the way that we experience the world.

Hard Determinism falls to the same flaws as Libertarian Free Will; a lack of hard evidence.  "[sic]..just because we can't pinpoint the exact factors that us to an action, we could, IN THEORY isolate them..."  'Theory' here is not 'scientific theory', like gravity, but 'we believe it to be true.'

On a pragmatic note, we should try to behave as if we have free will. No matter how low the odds, there's a chance that we've missed something in the evidence or analysis thereof which leads us to think determinism holds. We could be wrong, and free will could exist.

If determinism holds, the debate is over in pragmatic terms(though some of us may be determined to keep it going anyways). Whether there's an advantage to acting as if there is free will or not, well, you can't choose to act that way so it doesn't matter.

But if we have missed something, and free will does exist, then acting as if determinism holds may rob us of opportunities.

Okay, time to use the induction problem. Suzy enjoys eating chocolate ice cream bars from the same ice cream shop she visits each weekend. She has been purchasing a chocolate ice cream bar from the same shop each weekend as far back as her childhood. With that said, she should regularly anticipate that she will receive a chocolate ice cream bar continuously for the rest of her life within the causal chain, even as far back as she remembers. However, the same ice cream shop Suzy regularly visits each weekend since childhood, has no more chocolate ice cream bars, and so she has to settle for a vanilla ice cream bar (insert Vanilla Ice jokes here if you like). The point I am making is that the world only appears to be completely deterministic, because that is what we see from our memories, which we try to regularly connect to a continuity of events that unfold around us in the causal chain. Hence, that leaves room for free will to exist in our world.

I think there's an argument to be made that quantum mechanics makes determinism slightly problematic. If at the fundamental level of the universe events are probabilistic then it seems conceivable that those non-deterministic events could result in a random outcome when making a decision. Though we may want to withhold making generalizations using theory that's still being debated (there are several interpretations of the collapse of wave function for example) but I don't think it's so terribly difficult to shed some doubt on the theory of determinism.

Though this doesn't necessarily mean that you as a conscious entity are making the choice since the result is determined from some abstract probability but that starts to run into the issue of identity.

When you make a choice, you weigh options based on a number of criteria, whether that's subconscious or not. Originally, you made a choice to weigh options. If you didn't have free will, you wouldn't even bother to think about the options. You chose to consider them. And those options that presented themselves came about by other people's choices. We don't understand free will because it presents as an infinite regress of choices, even if you want to say that the choice you're making right now was no choice at all but forced, it was forced by someone else who made a choice. If they had chosen something else, your options would be different but you'd still have a free decision to make.

I wouldn't dismiss agency as the source of belief in free will since the subject might find that there will is free as long as there actions where not imposed by another. Even if there action was determined they still willed it.

Determinists conduct the double slit experiment. They want to determine which slit the particle goes through, so they observe them.
Results: Particles go through one, or the other, and end up in two areas behind the slits.
Free Willies conduct the double slit experiment. They let the particles freely choose whatever path they want without being observed and only check the results later.
Results: Probability waves.
QED. The universe is toying with us.

Edit: On a serious note, why not both?

There are things in the natural world that can be predicted to a high degree of certainty, and there are others that are unpredictable -- particularly when you start getting into things like the quantum realm, or self replicating molecules by the gazillions for example--. These are highly disparate realms which, in the case of QM vs. GR we still haven't reconciled yet, exist in the same universe; albeit at different scales or energies. We as biological beings have access to both realms, i.e. our bodies can affect, and be affected by the somewhat predictable macro world, and our minds, being electrically excitable information processors, inhabit the unpredictable realm of the very small and can also affect and be affected by the world.

Could there be some sort of phase change from the constrained and predictable, to one of almost limitless choices and unpredictability when you factor in minds that can remember, process, and combine gobs of pure information? I mean granted, me in all my babbling bipedal form may have been in a somewhat deterministic path thanks to the laws of physics and natural selection, but if I took the head of an Ostrich, the tail of a broom, ducktape them together, and then I do a dance around the object to the tune of Badger Badger Mushroom Mushroom, I can't see how accounting for all the particles and their positions could determine the inevitability of me doing such a thing.

The notion that every event is a necessary outcome of previous events is just wrong. When an event didn't happen, there is a wave of possibilities for what could happen. When you think about it, that "best argument for libertarianism"- that we simply have the subjective experience that there is free will- isn't at all bad, being that it's also the best argument that there exists a world outside our minds and that our sense impressions somewhat accurately represent it.
Personally, I find the conversation argument an interesting argument for libertarianism- what we say in a conversation is not random (we don't spout random words), also it is not determined by the conversation (we can spout random words) and yet it is appropriate to the conversation.

For further consideration: Thoughts are, physically speaking, the results of neurons 'firing' inside the central nervous system. Neurons firing or not is dependent on chemistry - but chemistry at (or below) the protein level is at a small enough for quantum physics to start playing a role. Quantum physics is, in part because of the uncertainty principle, stochastic (probability), and not deterministic in the classical way.
Does that mean free will is, essentially, the product of random events outside our direct control? Or does that mean reality is an ever-expanding poly-verse of probabilities where our perception of freedom is caused by only being able to observing one random path out of an infinite mass of possibilities? (and do all these paths exist and not exist concurrently in a way wholly 'inappropriate' for a macro-scale system?) Neither thought is particularly comforting.
